events.title: Marley's Undeniable Death and Scrooge's Miserly Nature
detailed_summary: The narrative emphatically establishes that Jacob Marley, Scrooge's former business partner, is unquestionably dead, providing details of his burial registry signed by Scrooge.
The narrator humorously reflects on the simile "dead as a door-nail," preferring a coffin-nail but ultimately respecting the traditional saying.

It's confirmed that Scrooge was fully aware of Marley's death, having been his only partner, executor, friend, and mourner, though Scrooge showed little grief and prioritized business even on the funeral day.

The narrator stresses the importance of accepting Marley's death as fact for the supernatural events of the story to have any impact, comparing it to the necessity of accepting Hamlet's father's death in the play.
Scrooge never removed Marley's name from the business sign, 'Scrooge and Marley,' answering to either name indifferentlly.
A detailed, harsh description of Scrooge's character is provided: avaricious, hard, emotionally closed-off, and physically marked by an inner coldness.
Scrooge's imperviousness to external weather conditions is highlighted, emphasizing that his internal bitterness surpassed any external cold or storm.
His social isolation is described: no one greeted him, asked him for help or directions, and even guide dogs avoided him, sensing his negative nature.

events.text_segment:
Marley was dead: to begin with. There is no doubt whatever about that. The register of his burial was signed by the clergyman, the clerk, the undertaker, and the chief mourner. Scrooge signed it: and Scrooge’s name was good upon ’Change, for anything he chose to put his hand to. Old Marley was as dead as a door-nail.
Mind! I don’t mean to say that I know, of my own knowledge, what there is particularly dead about a door-nail. I might have been inclined, myself, to regard a coffin-nail as the deadest piece of ironmongery in the trade. But the wisdom of our ancestors is in the simile; and my unhallowed hands shall not disturb it, or the Country’s done for. You will therefore permit me to repeat, emphatically, that Marley was as dead as a door-nail.
Scrooge knew he was dead? Of course he did. How could it be otherwise? Scrooge and he were partners for I don’t know how many years. Scrooge was his sole executor, his sole administrator, his sole assign, his sole residuary legatee, his sole friend, and sole mourner. And even Scrooge was not so dreadfully cut up by the sad event, but that he was an excellent man of business on the very day of the funeral, and solemnised it with an undoubted bargain.
The mention of Marley’s funeral brings me back to the point I started from. There is no doubt that Marley was dead. This must be distinctly understood, or nothing wonderful can come of the story I am going to relate. If we were not perfectly convinced that Hamlet’s Father died before the play began, there would be nothing more remarkable in his taking a stroll at night, in an easterly wind, upon his own ramparts, than there would be in any other middle-aged gentleman rashly turning out after dark in a breezy spot—say Saint Paul’s Churchyard for instance—literally to astonish his son’s weak mind.
Scrooge never painted out Old Marley’s name. There it stood, years afterwards, above the warehouse door: Scrooge and Marley. The firm was known as Scrooge and Marley. Sometimes people new to the business called Scrooge Scrooge, and sometimes Marley, but he answered to both names. It was all the same to him.
Oh! But he was a tight-fisted hand at the grindstone, Scrooge! a squeezing, wrenching, grasping, scraping, clutching, covetous, old sinner! Hard and sharp as flint, from which no steel had ever struck out generous fire; secret, and self-contained, and solitary as an oyster. The cold within him froze his old features, nipped his pointed nose, shrivelled his cheek, stiffened his gait; made his eyes red, his thin lips blue; and spoke out shrewdly in his grating voice. A frosty rime was on his head, and on his eyebrows, and his wiry chin. He carried his own low temperature always about with him; he iced his office in the dog-days; and didn’t thaw it one degree at Christmas.
External heat and cold had little influence on Scrooge. No warmth could warm, no wintry weather chill him. No wind that blew was bitterer than he, no falling snow was more intent upon its purpose, no pelting rain less open to entreaty. Foul weather didn’t know where to have him. The heaviest rain, and snow, and hail, and sleet, could boast of the advantage over him in only one respect. They often “came down” handsomely, and Scrooge never did.
Nobody ever stopped him in the street to say, with gladsome looks, “My dear Scrooge, how are you? When will you come to see me?” No beggars implored him to bestow a trifle, no children asked him what it was o’clock, no man or woman ever once in all his life inquired the way to such and such a place, of Scrooge. Even the blind men’s dogs appeared to know him; and when they saw him coming on, would tug their owners into doorways and up courts; and then would wag their tails as though they said, “No eye at all is better than an evil eye, dark master!”

events.title: Scrooge in his Bleak Counting-House on Christmas Eve
detailed_summary: Scrooge finds satisfaction in his isolation, preferring to keep humanity at a distance.
The narrative shifts to Christmas Eve, describing Scrooge occupied in his counting-house amidst cold, foggy weather.
The darkening afternoon and the surrounding environment are depicted, with candles lit in nearby offices and dense fog infiltrating Scrooge's premises.
Scrooge keeps his office door open to monitor his clerk, who works in a small, barely heated adjacent space ('the Tank').
Scrooge controls the coal supply, preventing the clerk from warming his meager fire, forcing the clerk to try warming himself futilely with his candle and comforter.

events.text_segment:
But what did Scrooge care! It was the very thing he liked. To edge his way along the crowded paths of life, warning all human sympathy to keep its distance, was what the knowing ones call “nuts” to Scrooge.
Once upon a time—of all the good days in the year, on Christmas Eve—old Scrooge sat busy in his counting-house. It was cold, bleak, biting weather: foggy withal: and he could hear the people in the court outside, go wheezing up and down, beating their hands upon their breasts, and stamping their feet upon the pavement stones to warm them. The city clocks had only just gone three, but it was quite dark already—it had not been light all day—and candles were flaring in the windows of the neighbouring offices, like ruddy smears upon the palpable brown air. The fog came pouring in at every chink and keyhole, and was so dense without, that although the court was of the narrowest, the houses opposite were mere phantoms. To see the dingy cloud come drooping down, obscuring everything, one might have thought that Nature lived hard by, and was brewing on a large scale.
The door of Scrooge’s counting-house was open that he might keep his eye upon his clerk, who in a dismal little cell beyond, a sort of tank, was copying letters. Scrooge had a very small fire, but the clerk’s fire was so very much smaller that it looked like one coal. But he couldn’t replenish it, for Scrooge kept the coal-box in his own room; and so surely as the clerk came in with the shovel, the master predicted that it would be necessary for them to part. Wherefore the clerk put on his white comforter, and tried to warm himself at the candle; in which effort, not being a man of a strong imagination, he failed.

But what did Scrooge care! It was the very thing he liked. To edge his way along the crowded paths of life, warning all human sympathy to keep its distance, was what the knowing ones call "nuts" to Scrooge.  

The cold within him froze his old features, nipped his pointed nose, shrivelled his cheek, stiffened his gait; made his eyes red, his thin lips blue; and spoke out shrewdly in his grating voice. A frosty rime was on his head, and on his eyebrows, and his wiry chin. He carried his own low temperature always about with him; he iced his office in the dog-days; and didn’t thaw it one degree at Christmas.  

External heat and cold had little influence on Scrooge. No warmth could warm, no wintry weather chill him. No wind that blew was bitterer than he, no falling snow was more intent upon its purpose, no pelting rain less open to entreaty. Foul weather didn’t know where to have him. The heaviest rain, and snow, and hail, and sleet, could boast of the advantage over him in only one respect. They often "came down" handsomely, and Scrooge never did.  

Nobody ever stopped him in the street to say, with gladsome looks, "My dear Scrooge, how are you? When will you come to see me?" No beggars implored him to bestow a trifle, no children asked him what it was o’clock, no man or woman ever once in all his life inquired the way to such and such a place, of Scrooge. Even the blind men’s dogs appeared to know him; and when they saw him coming on, would tug their owners into doorways and up courts; and then would wag their tails as though they said, "No eye at all is better than an evil eye, dark master!"  

But what did Scrooge care! It was all the same to him.

events.title: Confrontations Over Christmas Spirit and Charity
detailed_summary: Scrooge's cheerful nephew arrives unexpectedly, wishing him a Merry Christmas.
Scrooge dismisses the greeting with "Bah! Humbug!", questioning his nephew's right to be merry due to his poverty.
The nephew counters, questioning Scrooge's right to be dismal due to his wealth.
Scrooge launches into a tirade against Christmas, calling it a time for paying bills without money and suggesting violent ends for those who celebrate it.
The nephew defends Christmas as a good, charitable time, regardless of monetary gain, earning applause from the clerk, whom Scrooge threatens with dismissal.
Scrooge angrily rejects his nephew's dinner invitation, citing the nephew's marriage (due to love) as a ridiculous reason.
Despite Scrooge's repeated dismissals ("Good afternoon!"), the nephew maintains his festive spirit, wishes Scrooge a Merry Christmas and Happy New Year, and leaves after greeting the clerk cordially.
Scrooge mutters disdainfully about his clerk celebrating Christmas on a meager salary.
Two portly gentlemen enter, seeking a charitable donation for the poor in Scrooge's name or Marley's.
Scrooge confirms Marley's death seven years prior and reacts negatively to the mention of 'liberality'.
The gentlemen explain their cause, highlighting the suffering of the poor at Christmas.
Scrooge inquires dismissively about prisons and workhouses, expressing satisfaction that these institutions are operational.
He refuses to donate, stating he supports the existing establishments and that the poor should go there or die to "decrease the surplus population."
Declaring it's not his business, Scrooge dismisses the gentlemen, feeling pleased with himself.

“A merry Christmas, uncle! God save you!” cried a cheerful voice. It was the voice of Scrooge’s nephew, who came upon him so quickly that this was the first intimation he had of his approach.
“Bah!” said Scrooge, “Humbug!”
He had so heated himself with rapid walking in the fog and frost, this nephew of Scrooge’s, that he was all in a glow; his face was ruddy and handsome; his eyes sparkled, and his breath smoked again.
“Christmas a humbug, uncle!” said Scrooge’s nephew. “You don’t mean that, I am sure?”
“I do,” said Scrooge. “Merry Christmas! What right have you to be merry? What reason have you to be merry? You’re poor enough.”
“Come, then,” returned the nephew gaily. “What right have you to be dismal? What reason have you to be morose? You’re rich enough.”
Scrooge having no better answer ready on the spur of the moment, said, “Bah!” again; and followed it up with “Humbug.”
“Don’t be cross, uncle!” said the nephew.
“What else can I be,” returned the uncle, “when I live in such a world of fools as this? Merry Christmas! Out upon merry Christmas! What’s Christmas time to you but a time for paying bills without money; a time for finding yourself a year older, but not an hour richer; a time for balancing your books and having every item in ’em through a round dozen of months presented dead against you? If I could work my will,” said Scrooge indignantly, “every idiot who goes about with ‘Merry Christmas’ on his lips, should be boiled with his own pudding, and buried with a stake of holly through his heart. He should!”
“Uncle!” pleaded the nephew.
“Nephew!” returned the uncle sternly, “keep Christmas in your own way, and let me keep it in mine.”
“Keep it!” repeated Scrooge’s nephew. “But you don’t keep it.”
“Let me leave it alone, then,” said Scrooge. “Much good may it do you! Much good it has ever done you!”
“There are many things from which I might have derived good, by which I have not profited, I dare say,” returned the nephew. “Christmas among the rest. But I am sure I have always thought of Christmas time, when it has come round—apart from the veneration due to its sacred name and origin, if anything belonging to it can be apart from that—as a good time; a kind, forgiving, charitable, pleasant time; the only time I know of, in the long calendar of the year, when men and women seem by one consent to open their shut-up hearts freely, and to think of people below them as if they really were fellow-passengers to the grave, and not another race of creatures bound on other journeys. And therefore, uncle, though it has never put a scrap of gold or silver in my pocket, I believe that it has done me good, and will do me good; and I say, God bless it!”
The clerk in the Tank involuntarily applauded. Becoming immediately sensible of the impropriety, he poked the fire, and extinguished the last frail spark for ever.
“Let me hear another sound from you,” said Scrooge, “and you’ll keep your Christmas by losing your situation! You’re quite a powerful speaker, sir,” he added, turning to his nephew. “I wonder you don’t go into Parliament.”
“Don’t be angry, uncle. Come! Dine with us to-morrow.”
Scrooge said that he would see him—yes, indeed he did. He went the whole length of the expression, and said that he would see him in that extremity first.
“But why?” cried Scrooge’s nephew. “Why?”
“Why did you get married?” said Scrooge.
“Because I fell in love.”
“Because you fell in love!” growled Scrooge, as if that were the only one thing in the world more ridiculous than a merry Christmas. “Good afternoon!”
“Nay, uncle, but you never came to see me before that happened. Why give it as a reason for not coming now?”
“Good afternoon,” said Scrooge.
“I want nothing from you; I ask nothing of you; why cannot we be friends?”
“Good afternoon,” said Scrooge.
“I am sorry, with all my heart, to find you so resolute. We have never had any quarrel, to which I have been a party. But I have made the trial in homage to Christmas, and I’ll keep my Christmas humour to the last. So A Merry Christmas, uncle!”
“Good afternoon!” said Scrooge.
“And A Happy New Year!”
“Good afternoon!” said Scrooge.
His nephew left the room without an angry word, notwithstanding. He stopped at the outer door to bestow the greetings of the season on the clerk, who, cold as he was, was warmer than Scrooge; for he returned them cordially.
“There’s another fellow,” muttered Scrooge; who overheard him: “my clerk, with fifteen shillings a week, and a wife and family, talking about a merry Christmas. I’ll retire to Bedlam.”
This lunatic, in letting Scrooge’s nephew out, had let two other people in. They were portly gentlemen, pleasant to behold, and now stood, with their hats off, in Scrooge’s office. They had books and papers in their hands, and bowed to him.
“Scrooge and Marley’s, I believe,” said one of the gentlemen, referring to his list. “Have I the pleasure of addressing Mr. Scrooge, or Mr. Marley?”
“Mr. Marley has been dead these seven years,” Scrooge replied. “He died seven years ago, this very night.”
“We have no doubt his liberality is well represented by his surviving partner,” said the gentleman, presenting his credentials.
It certainly was; for they had been two kindred spirits. At the ominous word “liberality,” Scrooge frowned, and shook his head, and handed the credentials back.
“At this festive season of the year, Mr. Scrooge,” said the gentleman, taking up a pen, “it is more than usually desirable that we should make some slight provision for the Poor and destitute, who suffer greatly at the present time. Many thousands are in want of common necessaries; hundreds of thousands are in want of common comforts, sir.”
“Are there no prisons?” asked Scrooge.
“Plenty of prisons,” said the gentleman, laying down the pen again.
“And the Union workhouses?” demanded Scrooge. “Are they still in operation?”
“They are. Still,” returned the gentleman, “I wish I could say they were not.”
“The Treadmill and the Poor Law are in full vigour, then?” said Scrooge.
“Both very busy, sir.”
“Oh! I was afraid, from what you said at first, that something had occurred to stop them in their useful course,” said Scrooge. “I’m very glad to hear it.”
“Under the impression that they scarcely furnish Christian cheer of mind or body to the multitude,” returned the gentleman, “a few of us are endeavouring to raise a fund to buy the Poor some meat and drink, and means of warmth. We choose this time, because it is a time, of all others, when Want is keenly felt, and Abundance rejoices. What shall I put you down for?”
“Nothing!” Scrooge replied.
“You wish to be anonymous?”
“I wish to be left alone,” said Scrooge. “Since you ask me what I wish, gentlemen, that is my answer. I don’t make merry myself at Christmas and I can’t afford to make idle people merry. I help to support the establishments I have mentioned—they cost enough; and those who are badly off must go there.”
“Many can’t go there; and many would rather die.”
“If they would rather die,” said Scrooge, “they had better do it, and decrease the surplus population. Besides—excuse me—I don’t know that.”
“But you might know it,” observed the gentleman.
“It’s not my business,” Scrooge returned. “It’s enough for a man to understand his own business, and not to interfere with other people’s. Mine occupies me constantly. Good afternoon, gentlemen!”
Seeing clearly that it would be useless to pursue their point, the gentlemen withdrew. Scrooge resumed his labours with an improved opinion of himself, and in a more facetious temper than was usual with him.

Fred sighed but refused to be provoked. “Why? Why won’t you come? It’s only once a year.”  

“A good reason for never coming,” snapped Scrooge. “Leave me alone, nephew. Keep Christmas in your own way, and let me keep it in mine.”  

“But you don’t keep it,” Fred protested.  

“Let me leave it alone, then,” said Scrooge. “Much good may it do you! Much good it has ever done you!”  

Fred shook his head, still smiling. “There are many things from which I might have derived good, by which I have not profited, I dare say. Christmas among the rest. But I have always thought of Christmas time—when it has come round—as a good time: a kind, forgiving, charitable, pleasant time. The only time I know of, in the long calendar of the year, when men and women seem by one consent to open their shut-up hearts freely, and to think of people below them as if they really were fellow-passengers to the grave, and not another race of creatures bound on other journeys. And therefore, uncle, though it has never put a scrap of gold or silver in my pocket, I believe that it has done me good, and will do me good; and I say, God bless it!”  

The clerk in the tank, who had been listening with great admiration, involuntarily applauded. Realizing his mistake, he quickly seized the ruler and pretended to be very busy.  

Scrooge turned on him with a growl. “Let me hear another sound from you,” he said, “and you’ll keep your Christmas by losing your situation!” Then, to Fred: “You’re quite a powerful speaker, sir. I wonder you don’t go into Parliament.”  

“Don’t be angry, uncle. Come! Dine with us tomorrow.”  

Scrooge refused again, more vehemently than before, and Fred, seeing it was useless, rose to leave. But before he did, he clasped his uncle’s hand warmly.  

“I want nothing from you,” he said. “I ask nothing of you. Why cannot we be friends?”  

“Good afternoon,” said Scrooge.  

“I am sorry, with all my heart, to find you so resolute. But I have made the attempt in homage to Christmas, and I’ll keep my Christmas humor to the last. So a Merry Christmas, uncle!”  

“Good afternoon,” said Scrooge.  

“And a Happy New Year!”  

“Good afternoon!”  

Fred stopped at the door to bestow the greetings of the season on the clerk, who, though still fearful of Scrooge’s wrath, returned them heartily.  

And with that, Fred was gone, leaving the counting-house colder and darker than before.  

Scrooge returned to his work with renewed vigor, muttering to himself about fools and their holidays. But outside, the sound of carolers reached his ears, and for the briefest moment, he hesitated—just long enough for the ghost of a memory to flicker in his mind. Then he scowled and bent lower over his ledger, shutting out the sound, shutting out the light, shutting out the world.  

For Ebenezer Scrooge, Christmas was, and always would be, humbug.  

Or so he thought.  

But the night had other plans.

Meanwhile the fog and darkness thickened so, that people ran about with flaring links, proffering their services to go before horses in carriages, and conduct them on their way. The air was thick with the damp chill of December, and the streets of London seemed to swallow the feeble light of the lanterns whole, leaving only ghostly halos in their wake. Shop windows, though brightly lit, appeared as dim smudges in the gloom, their festive displays barely visible to the hurried passersby.  

Scrooge, wrapped in his heavy greatcoat, moved through the murk like a shadow himself, his sharp features set in their usual scowl. The jostling crowds paid him no mind, too absorbed in their own affairs—bundling against the cold, haggling over last-minute purchases, or murmuring of holiday plans. He heard snatches of laughter, the occasional burst of song, and the clinking of coins as charity collectors rattled their boxes. All of it grated on his nerves.  

A young boy, his face smudged with soot, darted in front of him, holding aloft a sputtering torch. "Light yer way, sir? Only a penny!" he called, his breath forming little clouds in the frigid air.  

Scrooge waved him off with a grunt. "Bah! I’ve no need for your light, nor your impertinence. Be off with you!"  

The boy’s hopeful expression faltered, but he was quick to turn to the next gentleman, who tossed him a coin with a merry chuckle. Scrooge sneered at the exchange. Foolish waste of money, he thought. As if a bit of flame could truly pierce this wretched gloom.  

Yet the fog seemed to press closer, as though resentful of his disdain. It curled around the lampposts, slithered between the cobblestones, and muffled the sounds of the city until even the clatter of hooves and wheels was dulled. The world had become a place of indistinct shapes and muffled voices, as if London itself were fading into some spectral realm.  

A sudden gust of wind sent a shudder through the crowd, and for a moment, the fog parted like a curtain, revealing a group of carolers gathered beneath a flickering streetlamp. Their voices rose in harmony, singing of goodwill and peace—words that struck Scrooge as bitterly ironic. What peace was there in a world of want and debt? What goodwill in the hearts of men who only thought of generosity when the calendar demanded it?  

He quickened his pace, eager to escape the sound, but the melody followed him, weaving through the fog like an insistent spirit. It stirred something in him—not warmth, not nostalgia, but a sharp, prickling irritation. Memories of long-ago Christmases, of laughter and feasting, rose unbidden, and he shoved them down with a growl.  

A link-boy, his torch guttering in the damp air, stepped into his path once more. "Sir, the way’s treacherous ahead—let me guide you!"  

Scrooge fixed him with a glare. "I know my way well enough without your help. Save your breath for those foolish enough to pay for it."  

The boy hesitated, then shrugged and moved on. Scrooge watched him go, the small flame bobbing like a will-o’-the-wisp before being swallowed by the fog. For the briefest instant, he felt a pang—not of guilt, surely, but something uncomfortably close.  

Shaking his head, he trudged onward, his boots splashing through icy puddles. The darkness deepened, and the city around him seemed to hold its breath, waiting.  

And though he would not admit it, even to himself, Scrooge felt the weight of the night pressing in—not just the fog, not just the cold, but something else, something unseen, watching.  

Waiting.

Scrooge took his melancholy dinner in his usual melancholy tavern; and having read all the newspapers, and beguiled the rest of the evening with his banker’s-book, went home to bed. He lived in chambers which had once belonged to his deceased partner. They were a gloomy suite of rooms, in a lowering pile of building up a yard, where it had so little business to be, that one could scarcely help fancying it must have run there when it was a young house, playing at hide-and-seek with other houses, and forgotten the way out again. It was old enough now, and dreary enough, for nobody lived in it but Scrooge, the other rooms being all let out as offices. The yard was so dark that even Scrooge, who knew its every stone, was fain to grope with his hands. The fog and frost so hung about the black old gateway of the house, that it seemed as if the Genius of the Weather sat in mournful meditation on the threshold.
Now, it is a fact, that there was nothing at all particular about the knocker on the door, except that it was very large. It is also a fact, that Scrooge had seen it, night and morning, during his whole residence in that place; also that Scrooge had as little of what is called fancy about him as any man in the city of London, even including—which is a bold word—the corporation, aldermen, and livery. Let it also be borne in mind that Scrooge had not bestowed one thought on Marley, since his last mention of his seven years’ dead partner that afternoon. And then let any man explain to me, if he can, how it happened that Scrooge, having his key in the lock of the door, saw in the knocker, without its undergoing any intermediate process of change—not a knocker, but Marley’s face.
Marley’s face. It was not in impenetrable shadow as the other objects in the yard were, but had a dismal light about it, like a bad lobster in a dark cellar. It was not angry or ferocious, but looked at Scrooge as Marley used to look: with ghostly spectacles turned up on its ghostly forehead. The hair was curiously stirred, as if by breath or hot air; and, though the eyes were wide open, they were perfectly motionless. That, and its livid colour, made it horrible; but its horror seemed to be in spite of the face and beyond its control, rather than a part of its own expression.
As Scrooge looked fixedly at this phenomenon, it was a knocker again.
To say that he was not startled, or that his blood was not conscious of a terrible sensation to which it had been a stranger from infancy, would be untrue. But he put his hand upon the key he had relinquished, turned it sturdily, walked in, and lighted his candle.
He did pause, with a moment’s irresolution, before he shut the door; and he did look cautiously behind it first, as if he half expected to be terrified with the sight of Marley’s pigtail sticking out into the hall. But there was nothing on the back of the door, except the screws and nuts that held the knocker on, so he said “Pooh, pooh!” and closed it with a bang.

He walked briskly, his breath forming little clouds in the frigid air, his thin lips pressed into a hard line. The thought of his lonely chambers awaiting him did not trouble him in the least, for he had long since grown accustomed to solitude.  

Upon reaching his dreary lodgings, he unlocked the door with his usual care, as though even the act of entering his own home required a miser’s caution. The house was dark and silent, save for the occasional creak of old timbers settling in the cold. He lit a single candle, its feeble glow doing little to dispel the gloom, and made his way up the creaking staircase.  

His bedchamber was as cheerless as the rest of the house—a narrow, sparsely furnished room with a bed that looked as though it had never known warmth or comfort. Scrooge undressed methodically, folding his clothes with the same precision he applied to his ledgers, and slipped beneath the threadbare blankets. The cold seeped into his bones, but he scarcely noticed. His thoughts, as always, turned to business—debts to be collected, investments to be weighed, profits to be counted.  

Yet, as he lay there in the darkness, something unusual occurred. A strange sensation crept over him, a prickling at the back of his neck, as though unseen eyes were watching him. He dismissed it as mere fancy, the result of an overworked mind, and turned his face to the wall. But the feeling persisted, growing stronger, until at last he could bear it no longer. He sat up abruptly, his heart pounding.  

The room was deathly still. The candle had long since burned out, leaving only the pale light of the moon filtering through the grimy window. And then—he saw it. A faint, ghostly glow at the foot of his bed, shimmering like mist upon the water. His breath caught in his throat as the glow took shape, forming the spectral figure of a man—a man he recognized with a shock that turned his blood to ice.  

It was Marley—Jacob Marley, his old business partner, dead these seven years. The apparition was clad in the chains he had forged in life, heavy with ledgers and cash-boxes that clinked and rattled with every movement. His face was deathly pale, his eyes wide and unblinking, fixed upon Scrooge with an expression of profound sorrow.

The sound resounded through the house like thunder. Every room above, and every cask in the wine-merchant’s cellars below, appeared to have a separate peal of echoes of its own. Scrooge was not a man to be frightened by echoes. He fastened the door, and walked across the hall, and up the stairs; slowly too: trimming his candle as he went.
You may talk vaguely about driving a coach-and-six up a good old flight of stairs, or through a bad young Act of Parliament; but I mean to say you might have got a hearse up that staircase, and taken it broadwise, with the splinter-bar towards the wall and the door towards the balustrades: and done it easy. There was plenty of width for that, and room to spare; which is perhaps the reason why Scrooge thought he saw a locomotive hearse going on before him in the gloom. Half-a-dozen gas-lamps out of the street wouldn’t have lighted the entry too well, so you may suppose that it was pretty dark with Scrooge’s dip.
Up Scrooge went, not caring a button for that. Darkness is cheap, and Scrooge liked it. But before he shut his heavy door, he walked through his rooms to see that all was right. He had just enough recollection of the face to desire to do that.
Sitting-room, bedroom, lumber-room. All as they should be. Nobody under the table, nobody under the sofa; a small fire in the grate; spoon and basin ready; and the little saucepan of gruel (Scrooge had a cold in his head) upon the hob. Nobody under the bed; nobody in the closet; nobody in his dressing-gown, which was hanging up in a suspicious attitude against the wall. Lumber-room as usual. Old fire-guard, old shoes, two fish-baskets, washing-stand on three legs, and a poker.
Quite satisfied, he closed his door, and locked himself in; double-locked himself in, which was not his custom. Thus secured against surprise, he took off his cravat; put on his dressing-gown and slippers, and his nightcap; and sat down before the fire to take his gruel.
It was a very low fire indeed; nothing on such a bitter night. He was obliged to sit close to it, and brood over it, before he could extract the least sensation of warmth from such a handful of fuel. The fireplace was an old one, built by some Dutch merchant long ago, and paved all round with quaint Dutch tiles, designed to illustrate the Scriptures. There were Cains and Abels, Pharaoh’s daughters; Queens of Sheba, Angelic messengers descending through the air on clouds like feather-beds, Abrahams, Belshazzars, Apostles putting off to sea in butter-boats, hundreds of figures to attract his thoughts; and yet that face of Marley, seven years dead, came like the ancient Prophet’s rod, and swallowed up the whole. If each smooth tile had been a blank at first, with power to shape some picture on its surface from the disjointed fragments of his thoughts, there would have been a copy of old Marley’s head on every one.
“Humbug!” said Scrooge; and walked across the room.
After several turns, he sat down again. As he threw his head back in the chair, his glance happened to rest upon a bell, a disused bell, that hung in the room, and communicated for some purpose now forgotten with a chamber in the highest story of the building. It was with great astonishment, and with a strange, inexplicable dread, that as he looked, he saw this bell begin to swing. It swung so softly in the outset that it scarcely made a sound; but soon it rang out loudly, and so did every bell in the house.
This might have lasted half a minute, or a minute, but it seemed an hour. The bells ceased as they had begun, together. They were succeeded by a clanking noise, deep down below; as if some person were dragging a heavy chain over the casks in the wine-merchant’s cellar. Scrooge then remembered to have heard that ghosts in haunted houses were described as dragging chains.
The cellar-door flew open with a booming sound, and then he heard the noise much louder, on the floors below; then coming up the stairs; then coming straight towards his door.
“It’s humbug still!” said Scrooge. “I won’t believe it.”
His colour changed though, when, without a pause, it came on through the heavy door, and passed into the room before his eyes. Upon its coming in, the dying flame leaped up, as though it cried, “I know him; Marley’s Ghost!” and fell again.

The sound resounded through the house like thunder, shaking the very timbers of the old building and rattling the windows in their frames. Ebenezer Scrooge, who had been sitting hunched over his ledgers in the dim candlelight, started violently, his quill scratching a jagged line across the page. His heart pounded in his chest as he strained his ears, listening for any further disturbance in the silent, frost-laden night.

"Bah!" he muttered, shaking his head. "Humbug! Nothing but the wind, no doubt." Yet even as he spoke, the words felt hollow. The noise had been too sharp, too deliberate to be mere weather. It had come from below—from the front door, he was certain of it. 

Scrooge set down his pen with deliberate slowness, as if to prove to himself that he was not afraid. He rose from his desk, his joints protesting the movement, and reached for the candle. The flame flickered wildly as he carried it before him, casting long, wavering shadows upon the walls. The house seemed to breathe around him, the old wood creaking as though it, too, were unsettled by the unnatural sound.

Step by cautious step, he descended the staircase, the worn wood groaning beneath his feet. The air grew colder with each step, his breath visible in the dim glow of the candle. When he reached the bottom, he hesitated, peering into the darkness of the hallway. The front door stood slightly ajar, a thin sliver of moonlight cutting across the floor. 

Impossible. He had bolted it himself. 

Scrooge’s fingers tightened around the candlestick as he approached, his pulse quickening. He reached out with his free hand, pushing the door open wider. The hinges gave a mournful creak, and the winter wind rushed in, carrying with it the scent of frost and something else—something metallic and strange. 

There, upon the doorstep, lay an iron chain. 

Not just any chain—this one was massive, each link as thick as a man’s wrist, coiled upon itself like a sleeping serpent. It gleamed dully in the moonlight, and as Scrooge stared at it, a terrible recognition dawned upon him. He had seen such a chain before—in his nightmares, in the ghostly visions that had plagued him since Marley’s death. 

A gust of wind howled through the open door, extinguishing the candle in his hand. Darkness swallowed him whole. 

And then—a sound. 

A dragging, clanking noise, as of heavy chains being pulled across the floor. It came from behind him, from within the house. 

Scrooge turned slowly, his breath coming in short, panicked gasps. The hallway was no longer empty. A figure stood there, shrouded in shadow, its outline flickering like a dying flame. The chains were wrapped around its body, wound so tightly they seemed to be part of its very flesh. 

"Who—who are you?" Scrooge demanded, though his voice trembled. 

The figure raised its head, and Scrooge staggered back with a cry. The face that stared back at him was Marley’s—but horribly changed. The skin was deathly pale, the eyes sunken and burning with an unnatural light. The mouth moved, but the voice that emerged was hollow, as though echoing from a great distance. 

"Ebenezer Scrooge..." it intoned. "You will be visited by three spirits..." 

Scrooge shook his head violently. "No! This is some trick—some madness!" 

Marley’s ghost let out a moan that seemed to shake the very foundations of the house. The chains around him rattled as he lifted a spectral hand, pointing at Scrooge. "Without their guidance, you cannot hope to escape my fate..." 

And with that, the ghost let out a final, anguished wail—and vanished, leaving Scrooge alone in the darkness, his heart pounding like a drum. 

For a long moment, he stood frozen, unable to move. Then, with a shuddering breath, he turned and fled back up the stairs, his mind racing. It had been a dream—it must have been. Yet even as he tried to convince himself, the memory of the chain, the ghost’s hollow eyes, and the terrible weight of its words lingered, refusing to be dismissed. 

He reached his bedchamber and slammed the door behind him, leaning against it as though to barricade himself against the unseen. His hands shook as he fumbled for a tinderbox, desperate for light. When at last the candle was lit, he scanned the room wildly, half-expecting to see Marley’s specter lurking in the corners. 

But there was nothing. Only the familiar, worn furniture, the cold hearth, and the relentless ticking of the clock. 

Scrooge sank into his chair, his legs no longer able to support him. He buried his face in his hands, trying to steady his breathing. 

"Three spirits..." he whispered. 

The night stretched before him, endless and foreboding. And though he did not yet know it, his life—and his very soul—would never be the same again.

detailed_summary: The ghost is unmistakably Marley, dressed as usual but with bristling hair and tassels.
A long chain made of cash-boxes, keys, ledgers, and purses is wound around its transparent body.
Scrooge, though seeing the ghost clearly, remains incredulous, fighting against his senses.
He addresses the ghost caustically, asking what it wants.
The ghost identifies itself as Jacob Marley, his former partner.
Scrooge hesitantly asks if the ghost can sit, which it does.
The ghost notes Scrooge's disbelief.
Scrooge attributes the vision to indigestion, claiming the ghost might be an undigested bit of food, making a pun about "gravy" and "grave."
Scrooge's attempt at humor is a defense mechanism against his mounting terror, caused by the ghost's voice and chilling presence.
The ghost's hair and clothes stir as if agitated by heat, despite its stillness.
Scrooge tries to distract himself by pointing to a toothpick, but the ghost affirms it sees it.
Scrooge insists it's all "humbug," prompting the ghost to let out a terrifying cry and shake its chain loudly.
The ghost then removes the bandage around its head, causing its lower jaw to drop onto its chest.
Terrified, Scrooge falls to his knees, pleading for mercy and asking why the apparition troubles him.
The ghost demands if Scrooge believes in him now, and Scrooge affirms he must.
Scrooge asks why spirits walk the earth and come to him.
Marley explains that spirits must walk among humanity in life; if they fail to do so, they are condemned to wander after death, witnessing the life they cannot share.
The ghost laments its fate, shaking its chain.
Scrooge asks why Marley is fettered.
Marley states he forged the chain himself in life through his selfish actions and asks if the pattern is unfamiliar to Scrooge.
He warns Scrooge that Scrooge's own chain was just as heavy seven years ago and has grown since.
Scrooge looks around but sees no chain.
He implores Jacob for comfort.
Marley replies he has none to give, as comfort comes from elsewhere for different people; he reveals he is permitted to say very little more and cannot rest.
He laments that his spirit was confined to their counting-house in life, leading to weary posthumous journeys.
Scrooge, reverting slightly to his business-like manner, remarks on the slowness of Marley's progress over seven years.

No, nor did he believe it even now. Though he looked the phantom through and through, and saw it standing before him; though he felt the chilling influence of its death-cold eyes; and marked the very texture of the folded kerchief bound about its head and chin, which wrapper he had not observed before; he was still incredulous, and fought against his senses.
“How now!” said Scrooge, caustic and cold as ever. “What do you want with me?”
“Much!”—Marley’s voice, no doubt about it.
“Who are you?”
“Ask me who I was.”
“Who were you then?” said Scrooge, raising his voice. “You’re particular, for a shade.” He was going to say “to a shade,” but substituted this, as more appropriate.
“In life I was your partner, Jacob Marley.”
“Can you—can you sit down?” asked Scrooge, looking doubtfully at him.
“I can.”
“Do it, then.”
Scrooge asked the question, because he didn’t know whether a ghost so transparent might find himself in a condition to take a chair; and felt that in the event of its being impossible, it might involve the necessity of an embarrassing explanation. But the ghost sat down on the opposite side of the fireplace, as if he were quite used to it.
“You don’t believe in me,” observed the Ghost.
“I don’t,” said Scrooge.
“What evidence would you have of my reality beyond that of your senses?”
“I don’t know,” said Scrooge.
“Why do you doubt your senses?”
“Because,” said Scrooge, “a little thing affects them. A slight disorder of the stomach makes them cheats. You may be an undigested bit of beef, a blot of mustard, a crumb of cheese, a fragment of an underdone potato. There’s more of gravy than of grave about you, whatever you are!”
Scrooge was not much in the habit of cracking jokes, nor did he feel, in his heart, by any means waggish then. The truth is, that he tried to be smart, as a means of distracting his own attention, and keeping down his terror; for the spectre’s voice disturbed the very marrow in his bones.
To sit, staring at those fixed glazed eyes, in silence for a moment, would play, Scrooge felt, the very deuce with him. There was something very awful, too, in the spectre’s being provided with an infernal atmosphere of its own. Scrooge could not feel it himself, but this was clearly the case; for though the Ghost sat perfectly motionless, its hair, and skirts, and tassels, were still agitated as by the hot vapour from an oven.
“You see this toothpick?” said Scrooge, returning quickly to the charge, for the reason just assigned; and wishing, though it were only for a second, to divert the vision’s stony gaze from himself.
“I do,” replied the Ghost.
“You are not looking at it,” said Scrooge.
“But I see it,” said the Ghost, “notwithstanding.”
“Well!” returned Scrooge, “I have but to swallow this, and be for the rest of my days persecuted by a legion of goblins, all of my own creation. Humbug, I tell you! humbug!”
At this the spirit raised a frightful cry, and shook its chain with such a dismal and appalling noise, that Scrooge held on tight to his chair, to save himself from falling in a swoon. But how much greater was his horror, when the phantom taking off the bandage round its head, as if it were too warm to wear indoors, its lower jaw dropped down upon its breast!
Scrooge fell upon his knees, and clasped his hands before his face.
“Mercy!” he said. “Dreadful apparition, why do you trouble me?”
“Man of the worldly mind!” replied the Ghost, “do you believe in me or not?”
“I do,” said Scrooge. “I must. But why do spirits walk the earth, and why do they come to me?”
“It is required of every man,” the Ghost returned, “that the spirit within him should walk abroad among his fellowmen, and travel far and wide; and if that spirit goes not forth in life, it is condemned to do so after death. It is doomed to wander through the world—oh, woe is me!—and witness what it cannot share, but might have shared on earth, and turned to happiness!”
Again the spectre raised a cry, and shook its chain and wrung its shadowy hands.
“You are fettered,” said Scrooge, trembling. “Tell me why?”
“I wear the chain I forged in life,” replied the Ghost. “I made it link by link, and yard by yard; I girded it on of my own free will, and of my own free will I wore it. Is its pattern strange to you?”
Scrooge trembled more and more.
“Or would you know,” pursued the Ghost, “the weight and length of the strong coil you bear yourself? It was full as heavy and as long as this, seven Christmas Eves ago. You have laboured on it, since. It is a ponderous chain!”
Scrooge glanced about him on the floor, in the expectation of finding himself surrounded by some fifty or sixty fathoms of iron cable: but he could see nothing.
“Jacob,” he said, imploringly. “Old Jacob Marley, tell me more. Speak comfort to me, Jacob!”
“I have none to give,” the Ghost replied. “It comes from other regions, Ebenezer Scrooge, and is conveyed by other ministers, to other kinds of men. Nor can I tell you what I would. A very little more is all permitted to me. I cannot rest, I cannot stay, I cannot linger anywhere. My spirit never walked beyond our counting-house—mark me!—in life my spirit never roved beyond the narrow limits of our money-changing hole; and weary journeys lie before me!”
It was a habit with Scrooge, whenever he became thoughtful, to put his hands in his breeches pockets. Pondering on what the Ghost had said, he did so now, but without lifting up his eyes, or getting off his knees.
“You must have been very slow about it, Jacob,” Scrooge observed, in a business-like manner, though with humility and deference.
“Slow!” the Ghost repeated.
“Seven years dead,” mused Scrooge. “And travelling all the time!”
“The whole time,” said the Ghost. “No rest, no peace. Incessant torture of remorse.”
“You travel fast?” said Scrooge.
“On the wings of the wind,” replied the Ghost.
“You might have got over a great quantity of ground in seven years,” said Scrooge.
The Ghost, on hearing this, set up another cry, and clanked its chain so hideously in the dead silence of the night, that the Ward would have been justified in indicting it for a nuisance.
“Oh! captive, bound, and double-ironed,” cried the phantom, “not to know, that ages of incessant labour by immortal creatures, for this earth must pass into eternity before the good of which it is susceptible is all developed. Not to know that no space of regret can make amends for one life’s opportunity misused! Yet such was I! Oh! such was I!”
“But you were always a good man of business, Jacob,” faltered Scrooge, who now began to apply this to himself.
“Business!” cried the Ghost, wringing its hands again. “Mankind was my business. The common welfare was my business; charity, mercy, forbearance, and benevolence, were, all, my business. The dealings of my trade were but a drop of water in the comprehensive ocean of my business!”
It held up its chain at arm’s length, as if that were the cause of all its unavailing grief, and flung it heavily upon the ground again.

“Hear me!” cried the Ghost. “My time is nearly gone.”
“I will,” said Scrooge. “But don’t be hard upon me! Don’t be flowery, Jacob! Pray!”
“How it is that I appear before you in a shape that you can see, I may not tell. I have sat invisible beside you many and many a day.”
It was not an agreeable idea. Scrooge shivered, and wiped the perspiration from his brow.
“That is no light part of my penance,” pursued the Ghost. “I am here to-night to warn you, that you have yet a chance and hope of escaping my fate. A chance and hope of my procuring, Ebenezer.”

“You will be haunted,” resumed the Ghost, “by Three Spirits.”

The same face: the very same. Marley in his pigtail, usual waistcoat, tights, and boots; the tassels on the latter bristling like his pigtail, and his coat-skirts, and the hair upon his head. The chain he drew was clasped about his middle. It was long, and wound about him like a tail; and it was made (for Scrooge observed it closely) of cash-boxes, keys, padlocks, ledgers, deeds, and heavy purses wrought in steel. His body was transparent; so that Scrooge, observing him, and looking through his waistcoat, could see the two buttons on his coat behind.  

Scrooge had often heard it said that Marley had no bowels, but he had never believed it until now. No, nor did he believe it even now. Though he looked the phantom through and through, and saw it standing before him; though he felt the chilling influence of its death-cold eyes; and marked the very texture of the folded kerchief bound about its head and chin, which wrapper he had not observed before; he was still incredulous, and fought against his senses.  

“How now!” said Scrooge, caustic and cold as ever. “What do you want with me?”  

“Much!”—Marley’s voice, no doubt about it.  

“Who are you?”  

“Ask me who I *was*.”  

“Who *were* you then?” said Scrooge, raising his voice. “You’re particular, for a shade.” He was going to say “*to* a shade,” but substituted this, as more appropriate.  

“In life I was your partner, Jacob Marley.”  

“Can you—can you sit down?” asked Scrooge, looking doubtfully at him.  

“I can.”  

“Do it, then.”  

Scrooge asked the question, because he didn’t know whether a ghost so transparent might find himself in a condition to take a chair; and felt that in the event of its being impossible, it might involve the necessity of an embarrassing explanation. But the ghost sat down on the opposite side of the fireplace, as if he were quite used to it.  

“You don’t believe in me,” observed the Ghost.  

“I don’t,” said Scrooge.  

“What evidence would you have of my reality beyond that of your senses?”  

“I don’t know,” said Scrooge.  

“Why do you doubt your senses?”  

“Because,” said Scrooge, “a little thing affects them. A slight disorder of the stomach makes them cheats. You may be an undigested bit of beef, a blot of mustard, a crumb of cheese, a fragment of an underdone potato. There’s more of gravy than of grave about you, whatever you are!”  

Scrooge was not much in the habit of cracking jokes, nor did he feel, in his heart, by any means waggish then. The truth is, that he tried to be smart, as a means of distracting his own attention, and keeping down his terror; for the spectre’s voice disturbed the very marrow in his bones.  

To sit, staring at those fixed, glazed eyes, in silence for a moment, would play, Scrooge felt, the very deuce with him. “Or would you know,” pursued the Ghost, “the weight and length of the strong coil you bear yourself? It was full as heavy and as long as this, seven Christmas Eves ago. You have laboured on it, since. It is a ponderous chain!”

“I have none to give,” the Ghost replied. “It comes from other regions, Ebenezer Scrooge, and is conveyed by other ministers, to other kinds of men. Nor can I tell you what I would. “You must have been very slow about it, Jacob,” Scrooge observed, in a business-like manner, though with humility and deference.  

“Slow!” the Ghost repeated.  

“Seven years dead,” mused Scrooge. “And travelling all the time?”  

“The whole time,” said the Ghost. “No rest, no peace. Incessant torture of remorse.”  

“You travel fast?” said Scrooge.  

“On the wings of the wind,” replied the Ghost.  

“You might have got over a great quantity of ground in seven years,” said Scrooge.

“Oh! captive, bound, and double-ironed,” cried the phantom, “not to know, that ages of incessant labour, by immortal creatures, for this earth must pass into eternity before the good of which it is susceptible is all developed. “Hear me!” cried the Ghost. “My time is nearly gone.”  

“I will,” said Scrooge. “But don’t be hard upon me! Don’t be flowery, Jacob! Pray!”  

“How it is that I appear before you in a shape that you can see, I may not tell. I have sat invisible beside you many and many a day.”  

It was not an agreeable idea. Scrooge shivered, and wiped the perspiration from his brow.  

“That is no light part of my penance,” pursued the Ghost. “I am here to-night to warn you, that you have yet a chance and hope of escaping my fate. A chance and hope of my procuring, Ebenezer.”  

“You were always a good friend to me,” said Scrooge. “Thank’ee!”  

“You will be haunted,” resumed the Ghost, “by Three Spirits.”  

Scrooge’s countenance fell almost as low as the Ghost’s had done.  

“Is that the chance and hope you mentioned, Jacob?” he demanded, in a faltering voice.  

“It is.”  

“I—I think I’d rather not,” said Scrooge.  

“Without their visits,” said the Ghost, “you cannot hope to shun the path I tread. Expect the first to-morrow, when the bell tolls One.”  

“Couldn’t I take ’em all at once, and have it over, Jacob?” hinted Scrooge.  

“Expect the second on the next night at the same hour. The third upon the next night when the last stroke of Twelve has ceased to vibrate. Look to see me no more; and look that, for your own sake, you remember what has passed between us!”  

When it had said these words, the spectre took its wrapper from the table, and bound it round its head, as before. Scrooge knew this, by the smart sound its teeth made, when the jaws were brought together by the bandage. He ventured to raise his eyes again, and found his supernatural visitor confronting him in an erect attitude, with its chain wound over and about its arm.  

The apparition walked backward from him; and at every step it took, the window raised itself a little, so that when the spectre reached it, it was wide open.  

It beckoned Scrooge to approach, which he did. When they were within two paces of each other, Marley’s Ghost held up its hand, warning him to come no nearer. Scrooge stopped.  

Not so much in obedience, as in surprise and fear: for on the raising of the hand, he became sensible of confused noises in the air; incoherent sounds of lamentation and regret; wailings inexpressibly sorrowful and self-accusatory. The spectre, after listening for a moment, joined in the mournful dirge; and floated out upon the bleak, dark night.  

Scrooge followed to the window: desperate in his curiosity. He looked out.  

The air was filled with phantoms, wandering hither and thither in restless haste, and moaning as they went. Every one of them wore chains like Marley’s Ghost; some few (they might be guilty governments) were linked together; none were free. Many had been personally known to Scrooge in their lives. He had been quite familiar with one old ghost, in a white waistcoat, with a monstrous iron safe attached to its ankle, who cried piteously at being unable to assist a wretched woman with an infant, whom it saw below, upon a door-step. The misery with them all was, clearly, that they sought to interfere, for good, in human matters, and had lost the power for ever.

**Expect the first to-morrow, when the bell tolls One.**  

These words, spoken by the Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come, lingered in Scrooge’s mind like the echo of a distant chime. The spectral visitor had shown him visions of a future shrouded in darkness—a future where his name was spoken with indifference, his wealth unclaimed, and his death unmourned. The final warning, delivered in silence, was clear: *Change, or face this fate.*  

As the ghost vanished into the shadows, Scrooge found himself clutching at his own bedpost, trembling yet strangely exhilarated. The cold night air still clung to the room, but his heart burned with newfound resolve. He had seen the consequences of his miserly ways, and the thought of dying alone, forgotten, struck him with a terror deeper than any ghostly visitation.  

“I will live in the Past, the Present, and the Future!” he vowed, his voice shaking with emotion. “The Spirits of all Three shall strive within me. I will not shut out the lessons that they teach!”  

And so, when the clock struck One the next day, Scrooge did not cower in fear—he *expected* it. He had spent the hours since dawn in a frenzy of repentance, laughing like a madman, weeping like a child, and embracing the world with a joy he had long forgotten. He threw open his window to the crisp morning air, hailed a passing boy with uncharacteristic cheer, and sent him to purchase the largest turkey in the shop for the Cratchit family.  

The boy, bewildered but eager for the promised shilling, dashed off as Scrooge chuckled to himself. “I’ll send it to Bob Cratchit’s! He shan’t know who sends it! It’s twice the size of Tiny Tim!” The mere thought of the frail child—whose fate he had seen hanging in the balance—filled him with a fierce determination. *No*, he would not let that future come to pass.  

When the church bell tolled One, Scrooge was already in the streets, his steps light, his heart lighter. He greeted strangers with a hearty “Merry Christmas!”—words he had once scorned—and marveled at how the world seemed brighter, kinder, as if his own transformation had cast a glow upon it.  

He sought out the portly gentlemen who had once asked him for charity and, with a flourish, pledged a generous sum—far more than he had ever considered before. Their stunned expressions delighted him. “And a Merry Christmas to you, sirs!” he cried, clapping them on the back before hurrying away, his laughter ringing through the frosty air.  

By the time he reached his nephew’s home that evening, Scrooge was nearly bursting with goodwill. Fred, who had long given up hope of his uncle’s company, gaped in astonishment as the old man swept in, declaring, “I’ve come to dinner! Will you let me in, Fred?”  

Laughter, music, and warmth enveloped him—things he had once dismissed as foolish. Now, they were treasures beyond price. As he sat among family, his heart full, he thought of the ghost’s warning: *Expect the first to-morrow.*  

And he had. Not with dread, but with hope. For the first time in years, Ebenezer Scrooge welcomed tomorrow—and every day after—with open arms.  

**The End.**

detailed_summary: Scrooge wakes up in complete darkness, unable to distinguish the window from the walls.
He hears a nearby church clock strike the quarter hours, followed by the bell tolling twelve times.
Astonished, as it was past two when he went to bed, he assumes the clock is broken.
He checks his own repeater watch, which also confirms the time as twelve.
Scrooge is bewildered, wondering if he slept through an entire day or if something unnatural has happened to the sun.
He gets out of bed and looks out the window, finding it very foggy and cold, with no signs of daytime activity.
This lack of daytime bustle relieves him slightly, as it means his financial contracts based on days are still valid.
Returning to bed, Scrooge endlessly contemplates the strange events, unable to make sense of them.
Thoughts of Marley's Ghost persistently return, making him question whether the encounter was real or a dream.
He lies awake until the clock chimes three quarters past twelve, suddenly remembering Marley's warning of a ghost's arrival at one o'clock.
Resolving to stay awake, considering sleep impossible anyway, he waits.
He fears he might have dozed off, but eventually hears the clock begin to strike the hour.

When Scrooge awoke, it was so dark, that looking out of bed, he could scarcely distinguish the transparent window from the opaque walls of his chamber. He was endeavouring to pierce the darkness with his ferret eyes, when the chimes of a neighbouring church struck the four quarters. So he listened for the hour.
To his great astonishment the heavy bell went on from six to seven, and from seven to eight, and regularly up to twelve; then stopped. Twelve! It was past two when he went to bed. The clock was wrong. An icicle must have got into the works. Twelve!
He touched the spring of his repeater, to correct this most preposterous clock. Its rapid little pulse beat twelve: and stopped.
“Why, it isn’t possible,” said Scrooge, “that I can have slept through a whole day and far into another night. It isn’t possible that anything has happened to the sun, and this is twelve at noon!”
The idea being an alarming one, he scrambled out of bed, and groped his way to the window. He was obliged to rub the frost off with the sleeve of his dressing-gown before he could see anything; and could see very little then. All he could make out was, that it was still very foggy and extremely cold, and that there was no noise of people running to and fro, and making a great stir, as there unquestionably would have been if night had beaten off bright day, and taken possession of the world. This was a great relief, because “three days after sight of this First of Exchange pay to Mr. Ebenezer Scrooge or his order,” and so forth, would have become a mere United States’ security if there were no days to count by.

events.title: Arrival and Description of the Ghost of Christmas Past
detailed_summary: Scrooge counts the chimes: quarter past, half-past, quarter to the hour.
The hour bell tolls a single, deep, melancholy note: One.
Instantly, light flashes in the room, and Scrooge's bed curtains are drawn aside by a hand.
Startled, Scrooge finds himself face-to-face with an unearthly visitor standing right beside his bed.
The visitor is described as a peculiar figure, resembling both a child and an old man simultaneously, as if viewed through a distorting lens.
Its hair is long and white like an old person's, yet its face is unwrinkled and youthful.
Its arms and hands appear unusually long and strong, while its legs and feet are bare and delicately formed.
It wears a pure white tunic, cinched with a beautiful, lustrous belt, and carries a branch of green holly.
Contradictorily, its white robe is trimmed with summer flowers.
The most striking feature is a bright jet of light emanating from the crown of its head, illuminating the scene.
It carries a large extinguisher cap under its arm, presumably to cover the light.

Scrooge observes that the figure's form fluctuates, its belt sparkling inconsistently, and its shape momentarily dissolving or changing—sometimes having one arm, then twenty legs, then just a head, before reforming clearly.

The transformation was nothing short of miraculous.

Below, the streets were alive with activity. Children, bundled in thick coats and scarves, darted through the snow, their laughter ringing as brightly as the church bells. events.title: The Spirit's Identity and Purpose Revealed

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
It would have been in vain for Scrooge to plead that the weather and the hour were not adapted to pedestrian purposes; that bed was warm, and the thermometer a long way below freezing; that he was clad but lightly in his slippers, dressing-gown, and nightcap; and that he had a cold upon him at that time. The grasp of the relentless Spirit was not to be resisted, and Scrooge found himself swept along with a force that defied all protest. The icy wind howled through the deserted streets, biting at his exposed flesh, yet the Ghost of Christmas Past moved forward undeterred, its luminous form casting an eerie glow upon the snow-laden cobblestones.  

Scrooge shivered violently, his breath forming ghostly plumes in the frigid air. "Spirit!" he gasped, clutching his thin dressing-gown tighter about his chest. "Must we venture forth in such bitter cold? I am but a feeble mortal, and this chill strikes to my very bones!"  

The Spirit turned its head slightly, its youthful yet ageless face regarding him with an expression neither cruel nor kind, but simply inexorable. "Your body shivers now," it said, its voice soft yet carrying the weight of centuries, "but it is your heart we must thaw, Ebenezer Scrooge. The cold you feel without is nothing to the frost that has long encased your soul."  

Before Scrooge could muster another plea, the world around them dissolved in a whirl of spectral light. The biting wind ceased, the snow vanished, and suddenly, they stood in a sunlit countryside, the air rich with the scent of blooming heather. Scrooge staggered, blinking in confusion, for the transition had been as swift as thought itself.  

"Where—?" he began, but the words died on his lips as his gaze fell upon a familiar lane, bordered by hedgerows heavy with summer foliage. A small boy, no more than eight years of age, trudged along the path, his head bowed, his shoulders slumped.  

Scrooge's breath caught. "That—that is me," he whispered, his voice trembling not with cold now, but with something far deeper.  

The Spirit nodded. "You recognize this place?"  

"Of course I do," Scrooge murmured, his eyes fixed upon the lonely child. "This is the road to my old school. I walked it many times, often alone, when other boys had gone home for the holidays."  

The scene shifted, and they stood now before a large, austere building—the school itself. Through the windows, they could see the young Scrooge seated at a wooden desk, his small frame hunched over a book. The room was vast and empty, the fire in the grate long since burned to ashes. No laughter echoed in those halls; no cheerful voices called his name.  

Scrooge swallowed hard. "I remember," he said hoarsely. "My father... he kept me here, even at Christmas. He said there was no reason for me to come home."  

The Spirit's gaze was piercing. "And how did that make you feel, Ebenezer?"  

For a moment, Scrooge could not answer. The weight of long-buried sorrow pressed upon his chest. "Alone," he admitted at last. "I felt so very alone."  

The vision changed again, and now the schoolroom was bright with candlelight, the air alive with music. A younger Scrooge, perhaps ten years old, sat with his sister Fan, her arms around him, her face radiant with joy.  

"Fan!" Scrooge cried out, his voice breaking. "Dear, dear Fan! She was the only one who ever cared for me then. She came to bring me home, despite Father's wishes."  

The Spirit watched as the memory unfolded—Fan's laughter, her promises that things would be better, that their father was kinder now. Scrooge's younger self clung to her, his eyes shining with hope.  

"You loved her," the Spirit observed.  

"More than anything," Scrooge replied, his throat tight. "She was the light of my life."  

"And yet," the Spirit said softly, "when she died, leaving only her son, you turned away from him as your father once turned from you."  

Scrooge flinched as though struck. The accusation hung in the air, heavy and inescapable. Before he could respond, the scene shifted once more, and they stood in the bustling warehouse of Fezziwig, where a younger Ebenezer, now a lively apprentice, laughed and danced alongside his fellow workers.  

"Good Heaven!" Scrooge exclaimed, his face lighting with unexpected delight. "Old Fezziwig! Bless his heart, there never was a better master!"  

The Ghost studied him. "Why was he so good, do you think?"  

Scrooge did not hesitate. "Because he knew that to make men happy cost little, yet the reward was great. A few pounds spent on a merry evening, and we were all richer for it!"  

The Spirit's eyes gleamed. "And yet you, who once praised such generosity, now count every penny, begrudge every crust of bread given to the poor. What changed, Ebenezer Scrooge?"  

The question struck like a dagger. Scrooge opened his mouth, but no defense came. The memories paraded before him—his gradual hardening, his obsession with wealth, his rejection of love in favor of gold. He saw Belle, his lost love, releasing him from their engagement with tears in her eyes, telling him that another idol had replaced her.  

"Spirit!" he groaned, covering his face. "Show me no more! I cannot bear it!"  

But the Ghost was merciless. "You must see what you have become, Ebenezer. Only then can you choose to change."  

And so the visions continued, each one peeling back another layer of Scrooge's hardened heart, until at last, he fell to his knees, weeping openly.  

"Leave me!" he sobbed. "Take me back! Haunt me no longer!"  

The Ghost regarded him silently for a long moment. Then, with a final, almost pitying glance, it began to fade. The warm light of the past dimmed, and Scrooge felt the cold of his own bedchamber closing in around him once more.  

Alone again, he collapsed upon the floor, his body shaking not with cold now, but with the terrible, glorious weight of self-awareness. The past had been laid bare before him—and with it, the first stirrings of redemption.

The Ghost smiled thoughtfully, and waved its hand: saying as it did so, “Let us see another Christmas!”
Scrooge’s former self grew larger at the words, and the room became a little darker and more dirty. The panels shrunk, the windows cracked; fragments of plaster fell out of the ceiling, and the naked laths were shown instead; but how all this was brought about, Scrooge knew no more than you do. He only knew that it was quite correct; that everything had happened so; that there he was, alone again, when all the other boys had gone home for the jolly holidays.

The Ghost smiled thoughtfully, and waved its hand: saying as it did so, “Let us see another Christmas!”  

Scrooge found himself transported once more, but this time to a bustling, lively scene. The air was thick with the scent of roasting chestnuts and spiced wine, and the streets were alive with laughter and song. He recognized the place at once—it was the very street where his old employer, Fezziwig, had once held his legendary Christmas parties.  

As they approached the familiar warehouse, the sound of fiddles and dancing feet grew louder. The Ghost led Scrooge inside, where the room was aglow with candlelight and warmth. There, in the midst of the merriment, stood a younger Ebenezer Scrooge, his face flushed with joy as he clapped along to the music. Beside him was Dick Wilkins, his fellow apprentice, both of them grinning from ear to ear.  

Old Fezziwig, round and jolly, danced with his wife, his laughter booming across the room. “A marvelous party, isn’t it?” the Ghost remarked, watching Scrooge’s face closely.  

Scrooge nodded, his throat tight with emotion. “It is indeed. Fezziwig knew how to make Christmas merry for all of us.”  

“A small matter,” said the Ghost, “to make these silly folks so full of gratitude. He spent but a few pounds of your mortal money—three or four, perhaps. Is that so much that he deserves this praise?”  

Scrooge’s eyes flashed with indignation. “It isn’t the money, Spirit! It’s the kindness, the generosity of heart. The happiness he gave us was worth far more than gold.”  

The Ghost’s smile deepened. “You see? The power to bring joy lies not in wealth alone, but in the willingness to share it.”  

Scrooge bowed his head, remembering how he had once dismissed such simple pleasures as foolishness. Now, seeing the scene anew, he felt a pang of regret for the years he had wasted in bitterness.  

The Ghost waved its hand again, and the scene shifted. They stood now in a modest but cozy home, where a young woman sat by the fire, her face a picture of quiet sorrow. Scrooge recognized her at once—Belle, the woman he had once loved.  

“Another Christmas,” the Ghost murmured.  

A knock came at the door, and Belle rose to answer it. There stood a younger Scrooge, his face already hardening with the beginnings of greed. “Ebenezer,” she said softly, “you have come at last.”  

“I have,” he replied, though his voice lacked warmth. “Belle, I must speak with you.”  

She nodded, stepping aside to let him in. The firelight flickered across their faces as they sat, the silence heavy between them. At last, Belle spoke. “You are changed, Ebenezer. The man I loved once placed happiness above wealth.”  

Scrooge watched his younger self stiffen. “The world is a hard place, Belle. A man must secure his future.”  

“But at what cost?” she asked gently. “You speak of gold as if it were the only thing of value. I release you, Ebenezer. I cannot marry a shadow of the man I once knew.”  

The younger Scrooge’s face twisted with anger, but beneath it, Scrooge now saw the fear—the terror of being alone, of never having enough. The vision blurred as Belle turned away, her tears glistening in the firelight.  

The present Scrooge reached out as if to stop her, but the Ghost held him back. “It is but a shadow of what has been,” it said. “You cannot alter it.”  

Scrooge’s hands trembled. “Spirit, show me no more! I cannot bear to see what I have lost.”  

The Ghost’s voice was gentle but firm. “These are the choices you made, Ebenezer. Yet it is not too late to change the path ahead.”  

With another wave of its hand, the scene dissolved, and Scrooge found himself standing once more in his own bedchamber, the Ghost beside him. His heart ached with the weight of memories, but for the first time in many years, he felt something else stirring within him—hope.  

“Spirit,” he whispered, “tell me there is still time.”  

The Ghost did not answer, but its smile was enough. The night was not yet over, and Scrooge knew that the lessons of the past could still shape his future—if only he had the courage to embrace them.
