events.text_segment:
Although they had but that moment left the school behind them, they were now in the busy thoroughfares of a city, where shadowy passengers passed and repassed; where shadowy carts and coaches battled for the way, and all the strife and tumult of a real city were. It was made plain enough, by the dressing of the shops, that here too it was Christmas time again; but it was evening, and the streets were lighted up.
The Ghost stopped at a certain warehouse door, and asked Scrooge if he knew it.
“Know it!” said Scrooge. “Was I apprenticed here!”
They went in. At sight of an old gentleman in a Welsh wig, sitting behind such a high desk, that if he had been two inches taller he must have knocked his head against the ceiling, Scrooge cried in great excitement:
“Why, it’s old Fezziwig! Bless his heart; it’s Fezziwig alive again!”
Old Fezziwig laid down his pen, and looked up at the clock, which pointed to the hour of seven. He rubbed his hands; adjusted his capacious waistcoat; laughed all over himself, from his shoes to his organ of benevolence; and called out in a comfortable, oily, rich, fat, jovial voice:
“Yo ho, there! Ebenezer! Dick!”
Scrooge’s former self, now grown a young man, came briskly in, accompanied by his fellow-’prentice.
“Dick Wilkins, to be sure!” said Scrooge to the Ghost. “Bless me, yes. There he is. He was very much attached to me, was Dick. Poor Dick! Dear, dear!”
“Yo ho, my boys!” said Fezziwig. “No more work to-night. Christmas Eve, Dick. Christmas, Ebenezer! Let’s have the shutters up,” cried old Fezziwig, with a sharp clap of his hands, “before a man can say Jack Robinson!”
You wouldn’t believe how those two fellows went at it! They charged into the street with the shutters—one, two, three—had ’em up in their places—four, five, six—barred ’em and pinned ’em—seven, eight, nine—and came back before you could have got to twelve, panting like race-horses.
“Hilli-ho!” cried old Fezziwig, skipping down from the high desk, with wonderful agility. “Clear away, my lads, and let’s have lots of room here! Hilli-ho, Dick! Chirrup, Ebenezer!”
Clear away! There was nothing they wouldn’t have cleared away, or couldn’t have cleared away, with old Fezziwig looking on. It was done in a minute. Every movable was packed off, as if it were dismissed from public life for evermore; the floor was swept and watered, the lamps were trimmed, fuel was heaped upon the fire; and the warehouse was as snug, and warm, and dry, and bright a ball-room, as you would desire to see upon a winter’s night.
In came a fiddler with a music-book, and went up to the lofty desk, and made an orchestra of it, and tuned like fifty stomach-aches. In came Mrs. Fezziwig, one vast substantial smile. In came the three Miss Fezziwigs, beaming and lovable. In came the six young followers whose hearts they broke. In came all the young men and women employed in the business. In came the housemaid, with her cousin, the baker. In came the cook, with her brother’s particular friend, the milkman. In came the boy from over the way, who was suspected of not having board enough from his master; trying to hide himself behind the girl from next door but one, who was proved to have had her ears pulled by her mistress. In they all came, one after another; some shyly, some boldly, some gracefully, some awkwardly, some pushing, some pulling; in they all came, anyhow and everyhow. Away they all went, twenty couple at once; hands half round and back again the other way; down the middle and up again; round and round in various stages of affectionate grouping; old top couple always turning up in the wrong place; new top couple starting off again, as soon as they got there; all top couples at last, and not a bottom one to help them! When this result was brought about, old Fezziwig, clapping his hands to stop the dance, cried out, “Well done!” and the fiddler plunged his hot face into a pot of porter, especially provided for that purpose. But scorning rest, upon his reappearance, he instantly began again, though there were no dancers yet, as if the other fiddler had been carried home, exhausted, on a shutter, and he were a bran-new man resolved to beat him out of sight, or perish.
There were more dances, and there were forfeits, and more dances, and there was cake, and there was negus, and there was a great piece of Cold Roast, and there was a great piece of Cold Boiled, and there were mince-pies, and plenty of beer. But the great effect of the evening came after the Roast and Boiled, when the fiddler (an artful dog, mind! The sort of man who knew his business better than you or I could have told it him!) struck up “Sir Roger de Coverley.” Then old Fezziwig stood out to dance with Mrs. Fezziwig. Top couple, too; with a good stiff piece of work cut out for them; three or four and twenty pair of partners; people who were not to be trifled with; people who would dance, and had no notion of walking.
But if they had been twice as many—ah, four times—old Fezziwig would have been a match for them, and so would Mrs. Fezziwig. As to her, she was worthy to be his partner in every sense of the term. If that’s not high praise, tell me higher, and I’ll use it. A positive light appeared to issue from Fezziwig’s calves. They shone in every part of the dance like moons. You couldn’t have predicted, at any given time, what would have become of them next. And when old Fezziwig and Mrs. Fezziwig had gone all through the dance; advance and retire, both hands to your partner, bow and curtsey, corkscrew, thread-the-needle, and back again to your place; Fezziwig “cut”—cut so deftly, that he appeared to wink with his legs, and came upon his feet again without a stagger.
When the clock struck eleven, this domestic ball broke up. Mr. and Mrs. Fezziwig took their stations, one on either side of the door, and shaking hands with every person individually as he or she went out, wished him or her a Merry Christmas. When everybody had retired but the two ’prentices, they did the same to them; and thus the cheerful voices died away, and the lads were left to their beds; which were under a counter in the back-shop.
During the whole of this time, Scrooge had acted like a man out of his wits. His heart and soul were in the scene, and with his former self. He corroborated everything, remembered everything, enjoyed everything, and underwent the strangest agitation. It was not until now, when the bright faces of his former self and Dick were turned from them, that he remembered the Ghost, and became conscious that it was looking full upon him, while the light upon its head burnt very clear.
“A small matter,” said the Ghost, “to make these silly folks so full of gratitude.”
“Small!” echoed Scrooge.
The Spirit signed to him to listen to the two apprentices, who were pouring out their hearts in praise of Fezziwig: and when he had done so, said,
“Why! Is it not? He has spent but a few pounds of your mortal money: three or four perhaps. Is that so much that he deserves this praise?”
“It isn’t that,” said Scrooge, heated by the remark, and speaking unconsciously like his former, not his latter, self. “It isn’t that, Spirit. He has the power to render us happy or unhappy; to make our service light or burdensome; a pleasure or a toil. Say that his power lies in words and looks; in things so slight and insignificant that it is impossible to add and count ’em up: what then? The happiness he gives, is quite as great as if it cost a fortune.”
He felt the Spirit’s glance, and stopped.
“What is the matter?” asked the Ghost.
“Nothing particular,” said Scrooge.
“Something, I think?” the Ghost insisted.
“No,” said Scrooge, “No. I should like to be able to say a word or two to my clerk just now. That’s all.”

Although they had but that moment left the school behind them, they were now in the busy thoroughfares of a city, where shadowy passengers passed and repassed; where shadowy carts and coaches battled for the way, and all the strife and tumult of a real city were. The air was thick with the mingled scents of coal smoke and roasting chestnuts, and the streets glistened with a thin layer of frost, as though the very cobblestones had been dusted with sugar.  

Scrooge, bewildered, clutched at the Spirit’s robe. “Good Heaven!” he cried. “To think that but a moment ago we stood in the quiet of my old schoolhouse, and now—this!”  

The Ghost of Christmas Past turned its luminous eyes upon him. “Does this place not stir your memory?” it asked.  

Scrooge hesitated, peering into the shifting crowd. Faces flickered in and out of view—some hurried, some laughing, some bent beneath the weight of their burdens. Then, suddenly, his gaze fixed upon a solitary figure, a young man walking briskly, yet with an air of distraction.  

“Why,” Scrooge murmured, “that is—that is myself!”  

Indeed, it was a younger Ebenezer, his coat threadbare but brushed with care, his expression a mixture of determination and unease. He moved through the throng as though he were both part of it and separate, his eyes darting toward the grand buildings that lined the street.  

“I remember this day,” Scrooge said slowly. “I was newly employed by old Fezziwig. It was my first Christmas in London.”  

The Spirit nodded. “And what do you recall of it?”  

Scrooge watched his younger self pause before a shop window, where a meager display of holiday goods—a few oranges, a twist of ribbon—lay halfheartedly arranged. The young man’s face fell, and he turned away with a sigh.  

“I had little money then,” Scrooge admitted. “I had hoped to buy some small gift for—for someone.” His voice faltered.  

The Ghost said nothing, but the scene shifted once more. Now they stood before a modest house, its windows glowing with candlelight. Inside, a family gathered—a father, a mother, and a young woman whose laughter was like the chime of silver bells.  

Scrooge’s breath caught. “Belle,” he whispered.  

She was as beautiful as he remembered, her dark curls framing a face alight with joy. She held up a simple gift—a handkerchief, embroidered with care—and her parents admired it with fond smiles.  

“She was expecting me that evening,” Scrooge said, his voice thick with regret. “I had promised to come, but—I did not. I stayed late at the counting-house, telling myself that I must work, that I could not afford the time.”  

The Ghost regarded him solemnly. “And why did you choose so?”  

Scrooge’s hands trembled. “Because I feared poverty. I had known want as a boy, and I was resolved never to know it again. I thought that if I could only amass enough, I should be safe. But—” His gaze lingered on Belle’s happy face. “But I lost something far greater in the pursuit.”  

The Spirit raised its hand, and the scene dissolved into mist. When it cleared, they stood in a different room—a parlor, where Belle sat alone, her face pale with sorrow. Across from her stood the younger Scrooge, his expression hard, his words measured and cold.  

“You have changed, Ebenezer,” Belle said softly. “The man I once loved valued kindness above gold. But now, I fear, your heart is given over to gain.”  

Young Scrooge’s jaw tightened. “The world is a harsh place, Belle. A man must secure his future.”  

She shook her head, tears glistening in her eyes. “There are futures beyond money, Ebenezer. Futures built on love, on joy. But you have closed your heart to them.” She drew a deep breath. “I release you. With a full heart, for the love of what you once were.”  

Scrooge, watching, let out a broken cry. “No—no, do not say it!” But the past could not be altered. He saw himself, young and stubborn, turn away from her. Saw Belle remove the ring from her finger and lay it gently upon the table.  

“Spirit!” Scrooge begged. “Show me no more! I cannot bear it!”  

But the Ghost was relentless. The room faded, and now they stood in a cheerful, bustling household. Belle, older now, sat surrounded by children, her husband’s hand resting warmly on her shoulder. The fire crackled, the room was bright with laughter, and the very air seemed to hum with contentment.  

“She married another,” Scrooge murmured. “And she is happy.”  

“Yes,” said the Ghost. “She found the happiness you might have shared, had you chosen differently.”  

Scrooge covered his face. “Leave me! Take me back! Haunt me no longer with what might have been!”  

The Spirit’s light dimmed slightly, as though in pity. “These are but shadows of the things that have been,” it said. “They are what they are. Do not blame me if they pain you.”  

Scrooge, trembling, reached out as if to grasp the happy scene before him—but it melted away like smoke. Once more, they stood in the cold, dark bedchamber, the Ghost’s hand upon his heart.  

“No more,” Scrooge pleaded. “No more. I cannot endure these memories.”  

The Ghost’s voice was gentle but firm. “You must, if you are to learn. One shadow more remains.”  

And before Scrooge could protest, the room dissolved into darkness once more.

events.title: Belle Ends Her Engagement to Scrooge
detailed_summary: As Scrooge voices his wish regarding his clerk, his former self dims the lamps, and he finds himself beside the Ghost in the open air again.
The Spirit announces its time is short and urges haste.
The scene changes, showing Scrooge again, but older, in his prime, his face beginning to show lines of care and avarice, with a greedy look in his eye.
He is not alone; a fair young woman named Belle, wearing mourning clothes, sits beside him with tears in her eyes.
Belle softly tells him that another idol, a golden one, has replaced her in his heart.
She states she has no cause to grieve if this new idol can comfort him as she would have tried to.
Scrooge asks what idol she means, and she confirms it is gold.
He defends his pursuit of wealth as a reaction against the world's harshness towards poverty.
Belle gently counters that he fears the world too much, and all his hopes have merged into acquiring wealth, letting his nobler aspirations die.
Scrooge retorts defensively, questioning if becoming wiser means he has changed towards her.
Belle shakes her head, asserting that he has changed significantly since their engagement, which was made when they were both poor and content.
She argues that what promised happiness then is now fraught with misery because they are fundamentally different people.
She asks rhetorically if he has ever sought release from their engagement.

When he asks how, she explains his release was sought not in words, but in his changed nature, altered spirit, different life focus, and the shift in his ultimate hope towards Gain, which devalued her love in his eyes.
She challenges him: if they were unattached, would he seek out and try to win her, a dowerless girl, now?
Scrooge seems to concede the point but struggles, saying, "You think not."

Belle affirms she knows he wouldn't choose her now, or if he did momentarily betray his principle of Gain, regret would follow; therefore, she releases him with a full heart, for the love of the man he used to be.
As he is about to speak, she turns away and continues.
She hopes he might feel brief pain from this memory but predicts he will quickly dismiss it as an unprofitable dream.
She wishes him happiness in his chosen life and departs.

events.text_segment:
His former self turned down the lamps as he gave utterance to the wish; and Scrooge and the Ghost again stood side by side in the open air.
“My time grows short,” observed the Spirit. “Quick!”
This was not addressed to Scrooge, or to any one whom he could see, but it produced an immediate effect. For again Scrooge saw himself. He was older now; a man in the prime of life. His face had not the harsh and rigid lines of later years; but it had begun to wear the signs of care and avarice. There was an eager, greedy, restless motion in the eye, which showed the passion that had taken root, and where the shadow of the growing tree would fall.
He was not alone, but sat by the side of a fair young girl in a mourning-dress: in whose eyes there were tears, which sparkled in the light that shone out of the Ghost of Christmas Past.
“It matters little,” she said, softly. “To you, very little. Another idol has displaced me; and if it can cheer and comfort you in time to come, as I would have tried to do, I have no just cause to grieve.”
“What Idol has displaced you?” he rejoined.
“A golden one.”
“This is the even-handed dealing of the world!” he said. “There is nothing on which it is so hard as poverty; and there is nothing it professes to condemn with such severity as the pursuit of wealth!”
“You fear the world too much,” she answered, gently. “All your other hopes have merged into the hope of being beyond the chance of its sordid reproach. I have seen your nobler aspirations fall off one by one, until the master-passion, Gain, engrosses you. Have I not?”
“What then?” he retorted. “Even if I have grown so much wiser, what then? I am not changed towards you.”
She shook her head.
“Am I?”
“Our contract is an old one. It was made when we were both poor and content to be so, until, in good season, we could improve our worldly fortune by our patient industry. You are changed. When it was made, you were another man.”
“I was a boy,” he said impatiently.
“Your own feeling tells you that you were not what you are,” she returned. “I am. That which promised happiness when we were one in heart, is fraught with misery now that we are two. How often and how keenly I have thought of this, I will not say. It is enough that I have thought of it, and can release you.”
“Have I ever sought release?”
“In words. No. Never.”
“In what, then?”
“In a changed nature; in an altered spirit; in another atmosphere of life; another Hope as its great end. In everything that made my love of any worth or value in your sight. If this had never been between us,” said the girl, looking mildly, but with steadiness, upon him; “tell me, would you seek me out and try to win me now? Ah, no!”
He seemed to yield to the justice of this supposition, in spite of himself. But he said with a struggle, “You think not.”
“I would gladly think otherwise if I could,” she answered, “Heaven knows! When I have learned a Truth like this, I know how strong and irresistible it must be. But if you were free to-day, to-morrow, yesterday, can even I believe that you would choose a dowerless girl—you who, in your very confidence with her, weigh everything by Gain: or, choosing her, if for a moment you were false enough to your one guiding principle to do so, do I not know that your repentance and regret would surely follow? I do; and I release you. With a full heart, for the love of him you once were.”
He was about to speak; but with her head turned from him, she resumed.
“You may—the memory of what is past half makes me hope you will—have pain in this. A very, very brief time, and you will dismiss the recollection of it, gladly, as an unprofitable dream, from which it happened well that you awoke. May you be happy in the life you have chosen!”
She left him, and they parted.

The night was bitter cold, and the wind howled through the empty streets like a mournful spirit. Scrooge shivered, though whether from the chill or the weight of the memories he had just witnessed, he could not say. The Ghost of Christmas Past stood beside him, its luminous presence casting an eerie glow upon the snow-covered cobblestones.  

Scrooge turned to the specter, his voice trembling. "Spirit," he said, "why have you shown me these things? Why must I revisit the sorrows of my past?"  

The Ghost regarded him with eyes that seemed to pierce his very soul. "The past shapes the present, Ebenezer Scrooge," it replied in a voice like distant chimes. "You carry these memories always, though you bury them deep. To change, you must first remember."  

Scrooge clenched his fists, his breath forming frosty clouds in the frigid air. "But what good does it do to dwell on what cannot be undone? I was a different man then—young, foolish!"  

"And yet," the Ghost murmured, "the choices of that young man have led you to this moment. Look again."  

Before Scrooge could protest, the world around them dissolved into mist, and suddenly, they stood in a bustling London street, alive with the sounds of laughter and merriment. It was Christmas Eve once more, but years earlier—a time when Scrooge had still clung to the warmth of human connection.  

There, among the throng of holiday shoppers, stood a younger Scrooge, arm in arm with a fair young woman. Her eyes sparkled with affection, but his own gaze was distant, already clouded by the creeping shadows of greed.  

"Belle," Scrooge whispered, his heart aching at the sight of her.  

The scene unfolded before them like a play. Belle spoke softly, her voice trembling. "Ebenezer, another idol has displaced me. A golden one."  

Young Scrooge frowned. "What idol has displaced you?"  

"Gain," she replied simply. "You fear the world too much. All your hopes have merged into the hope of being beyond its reach."  

Scrooge watched in agony as his younger self hesitated, then turned away, choosing wealth over love. The vision blurred, and when it cleared, Belle stood in a cozy parlor, surrounded by children, her face radiant with happiness. A kind-faced man—her husband—smiled at her with deep affection.  

"Spirit!" Scrooge cried, his voice breaking. "Show me no more! Must I see what I have lost?"  

The Ghost's light dimmed slightly. "You asked to see these memories, Ebenezer. They are not mine to conceal."  

Scrooge covered his face, the weight of regret pressing upon him like a stone. "She was happy without me," he muttered. "She found joy, while I—" His words faltered as the truth struck him. He had built a fortress of gold, only to find himself a prisoner within it.  

The Ghost extended a hand, and the scene shifted once more. Now they stood in a graveyard, the air thick with silence. Before them stood a solitary headstone, its inscription weathered but legible. Scrooge approached it with dread, his fingers trembling as he traced the letters.  

"Ebenezer Scrooge," he read aloud, his voice hollow.  

A cold terror seized him. "Am I to see my own death, Spirit?"  

The Ghost did not answer, but the grave seemed to yawn before him, whispering of a life unlived, of love ungiven, of a name remembered only with scorn.  

Scrooge fell to his knees, the snow soaking through his trousers. "No! I will not end like this! Tell me there is still time!"  

The Ghost's light flickered, and for the first time, its expression softened. "It is not for me to say what may yet be, Ebenezer. That is for you to decide."

The Ghost of Christmas Past was gone, leaving only the faintest echo of its presence—a lingering warmth, like the memory of a forgotten kindness.  

Scrooge clutched the bedpost, his breath coming in ragged gasps. "I will change," he vowed to the empty room. "I will honor Christmas in my heart, and try to keep it all the year!"

events.title: Witnessing Lost Happiness and Extinguishing the Spirit
detailed_summary: Deeply distressed, Scrooge begs the Spirit to show him no more and take him home, questioning why it delights in torturing him.
The Ghost insists on showing "One shadow more."
Scrooge vehemently refuses, but the relentless Ghost physically restrains him, forcing him to watch.
They are transported to another scene: a comfortable, though not large or grand, room.
Belle, now a comely matron, sits near the fire opposite her daughter, surrounded by a tumultuous crowd of happy children.
The mother and daughter laugh heartily at the children's boisterous play.
A knock at the door prompts a rush, with Belle carried towards it by the excited children just as her husband enters, accompanied by a man laden with Christmas toys.
Joyful chaos ensues as the children playfully attack the porter to get the presents.
The scene depicts indescribable joy, gratitude, and ecstasy as packages are opened.
Eventually, the children and their excitement move upstairs to bed.
Scrooge watches intently as the husband sits by the fire with Belle and their daughter.
The thought that such a graceful creature could have been his daughter, bringing light to his bleak life, dims Scrooge's eyes.
Belle's husband tells her he saw an old friend of hers that afternoon: Mr. Scrooge.
He recounts passing Scrooge's office, seeing him alone by candlelight, noting that Scrooge's partner (Marley) is near death, and remarking, "Quite alone in the world, I do believe."
Hearing this, Scrooge, in a broken voice, pleads with the Spirit to remove him.
The Ghost reminds him these are unalterable shadows of the past and not its fault.
Scrooge cries, "Remove me! I cannot bear it!"
He turns on the Ghost, noticing its face seems to contain fragments of all the faces shown.
He wrestles with the Spirit, which offers no physical resistance.
Observing the Spirit's light burning brightly, Scrooge connects it to the Spirit's influence over him.
He seizes the extinguisher cap and suddenly forces it down over the Spirit's head.
The Spirit sinks beneath the cap, but despite Scrooge pressing down with all his might, its light streams out from under the edge in an unbroken flood.
Scrooge suddenly feels exhausted and overwhelmingly drowsy, becoming aware he is back in his own bedroom.
He gives the cap a final squeeze as his hand relaxes, then barely manages to stumble to bed before falling into a deep sleep.

events.text_segment:
“Spirit!” said Scrooge, “show me no more! Conduct me home. Why do you delight to torture me?”
“One shadow more!” exclaimed the Ghost.
“No more!” cried Scrooge. “No more. I don’t wish to see it. Show me no more!”
But the relentless Ghost pinioned him in both his arms, and forced him to observe what happened next.
They were in another scene and place; a room, not very large or handsome, but full of comfort. Near to the winter fire sat a beautiful young girl, so like that last that Scrooge believed it was the same, until he saw her, now a comely matron, sitting opposite her daughter. The noise in this room was perfectly tumultuous, for there were more children there, than Scrooge in his agitated state of mind could count; and, unlike the celebrated herd in the poem, they were not forty children conducting themselves like one, but every child was conducting itself like forty. The consequences were uproarious beyond belief; but no one seemed to care; on the contrary, the mother and daughter laughed heartily, and enjoyed it very much; and the latter, soon beginning to mingle in the sports, got pillaged by the young brigands most ruthlessly. What would I not have given to be one of them! Though I never could have been so rude, no, no! I wouldn’t for the wealth of all the world have crushed that braided hair, and torn it down; and for the precious little shoe, I wouldn’t have plucked it off, God bless my soul! to save my life. As to measuring her waist in sport, as they did, bold young brood, I couldn’t have done it; I should have expected my arm to have grown round it for a punishment, and never come straight again. And yet I should have dearly liked, I own, to have touched her lips; to have questioned her, that she might have opened them; to have looked upon the lashes of her downcast eyes, and never raised a blush; to have let loose waves of hair, an inch of which would be a keepsake beyond price: in short, I should have liked, I do confess, to have had the lightest licence of a child, and yet to have been man enough to know its value.
But now a knocking at the door was heard, and such a rush immediately ensued that she with laughing face and plundered dress was borne towards it the centre of a flushed and boisterous group, just in time to greet the father, who came home attended by a man laden with Christmas toys and presents. Then the shouting and the struggling, and the onslaught that was made on the defenceless porter! The scaling him with chairs for ladders to dive into his pockets, despoil him of brown-paper parcels, hold on tight by his cravat, hug him round his neck, pommel his back, and kick his legs in irrepressible affection! The shouts of wonder and delight with which the development of every package was received! The terrible announcement that the baby had been taken in the act of putting a doll’s frying-pan into his mouth, and was more than suspected of having swallowed a fictitious turkey, glued on a wooden platter! The immense relief of finding this a false alarm! The joy, and gratitude, and ecstasy! They are all indescribable alike. It is enough that by degrees the children and their emotions got out of the parlour, and by one stair at a time, up to the top of the house; where they went to bed, and so subsided.
And now Scrooge looked on more attentively than ever, when the master of the house, having his daughter leaning fondly on him, sat down with her and her mother at his own fireside; and when he thought that such another creature, quite as graceful and as full of promise, might have called him father, and been a spring-time in the haggard winter of his life, his sight grew very dim indeed.
“Belle,” said the husband, turning to his wife with a smile, “I saw an old friend of yours this afternoon.”
“Who was it?”
“Guess!”
“How can I? Tut, don’t I know?” she added in the same breath, laughing as he laughed. “Mr. Scrooge.”
“Mr. Scrooge it was. I passed his office window; and as it was not shut up, and he had a candle inside, I could scarcely help seeing him. His partner lies upon the point of death, I hear; and there he sat alone. Quite alone in the world, I do believe.”
“Spirit!” said Scrooge in a broken voice, “remove me from this place.”
“I told you these were shadows of the things that have been,” said the Ghost. “That they are what they are, do not blame me!”
“Remove me!” Scrooge exclaimed, “I cannot bear it!”
He turned upon the Ghost, and seeing that it looked upon him with a face, in which in some strange way there were fragments of all the faces it had shown him, wrestled with it.
“Leave me! Take me back. Haunt me no longer!”
In the struggle, if that can be called a struggle in which the Ghost with no visible resistance on its own part was undisturbed by any effort of its adversary, Scrooge observed that its light was burning high and bright; and dimly connecting that with its influence over him, he seized the extinguisher-cap, and by a sudden action pressed it down upon its head.
The Spirit dropped beneath it, so that the extinguisher covered its whole form; but though Scrooge pressed it down with all his force, he could not hide the light: which streamed from under it, in an unbroken flood upon the ground.
He was conscious of being exhausted, and overcome by an irresistible drowsiness; and, further, of being in his own bedroom. He gave the cap a parting squeeze, in which his hand relaxed; and had barely time to reel to bed, before he sank into a heavy sleep.

The Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come remained silent, its spectral hand still outstretched toward the grim scene before them—a lonely grave, neglected and overgrown, bearing Scrooge’s own name upon the weathered stone. The Spirit did not answer, but its hooded head inclined slightly, as if in contemplation. Then, with a motion like the closing of a book, the graveyard dissolved around them, and Scrooge felt himself whirled through darkness once more.  

When the world reformed, he found himself standing in his own bedchamber. The pale light of dawn crept through the curtains, and the familiar furnishings of his room surrounded him—the four-poster bed, the heavy drapes, the dying embers in the hearth. He was alone. The Phantom had vanished.  

For a moment, Scrooge stood frozen, his hands trembling. Then, with a sudden burst of energy, he rushed to the window and threw it open. The crisp morning air rushed in, carrying with it the sounds of the waking city—the cheerful cries of street vendors, the distant peal of church bells, the laughter of children already at play.  

“It’s Christmas Day!” Scrooge exclaimed, his voice cracking with emotion. “I haven’t missed it! The Spirits have done it all in one night!” He laughed aloud, a sound so foreign to his own ears that it startled him. “I am as light as a feather, I am as happy as an angel, I am as merry as a schoolboy!”  

He dressed himself with frantic haste, his fingers fumbling with buttons in his excitement. “I must do something! Scrooge threw open his door and nearly collided with a young boy lingering in the street below. “You there, boy!” he called. “What’s today?”  

The child, startled, blinked up at him. “Why, it’s Christmas Day, sir!”  

“Christmas Day!” Scrooge repeated, clapping his hands together. “Then there’s still time! Listen, my lad—do you know the poulterer’s shop in the next street but one?”  

The boy nodded.  

“A splendid turkey hangs there—the biggest, the finest they have! Go and buy it for me at once! Tell them to bring it here, and I’ll give you half a crown for your trouble!”  

The boy’s eyes widened. “A whole crown, sir?”  

“No, no—half a crown!” Scrooge corrected, then paused. “Ah, what’s the difference? Here’s a whole crown for you—only hurry back!”  

The boy dashed off like a shot, and Scrooge, chuckling to himself, turned back inside to finish dressing. His heart swelled with a joy he had not known in decades. He would right his wrongs. He would mend the broken threads of his life.  

And when the turkey arrived—an enormous, glorious bird—he directed the delivery boy to take it straight to Bob Cratchit’s house, with strict instructions not to reveal the sender. The thought of Tiny Tim’s face when he saw such a feast nearly brought tears to Scrooge’s eyes.  

Then, donning his finest coat, he stepped out into the bright morning, his steps quick and light. He would go to church, he decided. And afterward—why, he would surprise his nephew Fred and beg forgiveness for years of bitterness.  

As he walked, he greeted every passerby with a cheerful “Merry Christmas!”—startling more than a few who knew him only as a miserly old wretch. But Scrooge did not care. The weight of his past was lifted, and the future stretched before him, bright with promise.  

For the first time in many long years, Ebenezer Scrooge understood what it truly meant to keep Christmas in his heart. And he vowed, as long as he lived, he would honor it—not just on this day, but every day of the year.  

**THE END**

detailed_summary: Scrooge awakens exactly at one o'clock, fully conscious and prepared for his pre-arranged meeting with the second spirit.
Feeling uneasy about where the ghost might emerge, he takes the initiative to pull aside all his bed curtains himself and lies down, keeping watch.
The narrator emphasizes Scrooge's readiness for a wide range of strange phenomena, suggesting almost nothing could greatly surprise him.
However, when the clock strikes one and no spirit appears, Scrooge is unexpectedly overcome by intense trembling.
Minutes pass with no apparition, while Scrooge remains lying in bed, illuminated by a strong reddish light flooding his room from the adjacent chamber.
This unexplained light proves more unnerving than ghosts, as Scrooge cannot discern its source or purpose, even briefly fearing he might be undergoing spontaneous combustion.
Finally, he reasons that the light must originate from the next room and cautiously approaches the door.
Just as his hand reaches the lock, an unfamiliar voice distinctly calls him by name and instructs him to enter.
He obeys and finds himself in his own room, yet it has undergone a dramatic and festive transformation.
The walls and ceiling are entirely covered with living greenery—holly, mistletoe, and ivy—making it resemble a grove, with gleaming berries sparkling everywhere.
A massive fire blazes in the hearth, far grander than Scrooge or Marley ever had.
A veritable throne constructed from an immense pile of Christmas foods dominates the floor: poultry, meats, sausages, pies, puddings, oysters, fruits, and steaming punch bowls.

Comfortably seated upon this throne of abundance is a large, cheerful, glorious Giant holding a glowing torch shaped like Plenty's horn, which he raises to illuminate Scrooge peeking through the doorway.

Awaking in the middle of a prodigiously tough snore, and sitting up in bed to get his thoughts together, Scrooge had no occasion to be told that the bell was again upon the stroke of One. He felt that he was restored to consciousness in the right nick of time, for the especial purpose of holding a conference with the second messenger despatched to him through Jacob Marley’s intervention. But finding that he turned uncomfortably cold when he began to wonder which of his curtains this new spectre would draw back, he put them every one aside with his own hands; and lying down again, established a sharp look-out all round the bed. For he wished to challenge the Spirit on the moment of its appearance, and did not wish to be taken by surprise, and made nervous.
Gentlemen of the free-and-easy sort, who plume themselves on being acquainted with a move or two, and being usually equal to the time-of-day, express the wide range of their capacity for adventure by observing that they are good for anything from pitch-and-toss to manslaughter; between which opposite extremes, no doubt, there lies a tolerably wide and comprehensive range of subjects. Without venturing for Scrooge quite as hardily as this, I don’t mind calling on you to believe that he was ready for a good broad field of strange appearances, and that nothing between a baby and rhinoceros would have astonished him very much.
Now, being prepared for almost anything, he was not by any means prepared for nothing; and, consequently, when the Bell struck One, and no shape appeared, he was taken with a violent fit of trembling. Five minutes, ten minutes, a quarter of an hour went by, yet nothing came. All this time, he lay upon his bed, the very core and centre of a blaze of ruddy light, which streamed upon it when the clock proclaimed the hour; and which, being only light, was more alarming than a dozen ghosts, as he was powerless to make out what it meant, or would be at; and was sometimes apprehensive that he might be at that very moment an interesting case of spontaneous combustion, without having the consolation of knowing it. At last, however, he began to think—as you or I would have thought at first; for it is always the person not in the predicament who knows what ought to have been done in it, and would unquestionably have done it too—at last, I say, he began to think that the source and secret of this ghostly light might be in the adjoining room, from whence, on further tracing it, it seemed to shine. This idea taking full possession of his mind, he got up softly and shuffled in his slippers to the door.
The moment Scrooge’s hand was on the lock, a strange voice called him by his name, and bade him enter. He obeyed.
It was his own room. There was no doubt about that. But it had undergone a surprising transformation. The walls and ceiling were so hung with living green, that it looked a perfect grove; from every part of which, bright gleaming berries glistened. The crisp leaves of holly, mistletoe, and ivy reflected back the light, as if so many little mirrors had been scattered there; and such a mighty blaze went roaring up the chimney, as that dull petrification of a hearth had never known in Scrooge’s time, or Marley’s, or for many and many a winter season gone. Heaped up on the floor, to form a kind of throne, were turkeys, geese, game, poultry, brawn, great joints of meat, sucking-pigs, long wreaths of sausages, mince-pies, plum-puddings, barrels of oysters, red-hot chestnuts, cherry-cheeked apples, juicy oranges, luscious pears, immense twelfth-cakes, and seething bowls of punch, that made the chamber dim with their delicious steam. In easy state upon this couch, there sat a jolly Giant, glorious to see; who bore a glowing torch, in shape not unlike Plenty’s horn, and held it up, high up, to shed its light on Scrooge, as he came peeping round the door.

The silence of the night pressed heavily upon him, broken only by the distant chime of the church clock, its solemn tone reverberating through the frost-laden air. He shivered, though not from the cold—for the fire in his chamber still burned low and steady—but from the lingering dread of the spectral visitations that had thus far disturbed his rest.  

He rubbed his eyes, half-expecting to see another ghostly figure materialize before him. The room, however, remained empty, save for the dim glow of the embers casting long, flickering shadows upon the walls. Yet Scrooge could not shake the feeling that he was not alone. The air itself seemed charged with an unseen presence, as though the very walls were listening, waiting.  

Then, without warning, a sound—soft at first, like the rustling of silk—grew louder, until it filled the chamber with an eerie, unearthly music. Scrooge stiffened, his breath catching in his throat. The curtains of his bed were drawn aside by an invisible hand, and there, before him, stood a figure draped in a deep black garment, its face concealed within the folds of a hood.  

Scrooge’s heart pounded as the specter raised a bony finger and beckoned him forward. Though every instinct screamed at him to resist, he found himself compelled to rise, his feet moving as though guided by some unseen force. The ghost said nothing, yet its silence was more terrible than any words could have been.  

They passed through the wall as though it were mist, emerging into a scene that chilled Scrooge to his very soul. A desolate churchyard stretched before them, the gravestones crooked and weathered, their inscriptions worn away by time. A biting wind howled through the barren trees, and the moon, pale and sickly, cast a ghastly light upon the earth.  

The phantom halted before a neglected grave, its finger now pointing downward at the crumbling stone. Scrooge’s knees trembled as he leaned closer, brushing away the moss and dirt to reveal his own name etched upon the cold marble: *Ebenezer Scrooge*.  

A cry of horror escaped his lips. "No! Spirit, tell me this is not my fate!"  

The ghost remained silent, its hollow gaze fixed upon him.  

"Am I to die alone, unmourned?" Scrooge pleaded, his voice breaking. "Is there no hope for me?"  

Still, the specter gave no answer, but the weight of its presence seemed to press upon Scrooge’s chest, crushing him with the certainty of his own mortality.  

Then, in an instant, the vision dissolved. Scrooge found himself back in his bedchamber, gasping as though he had been drowning. The fire had dwindled to ashes, and the first pale light of dawn crept through the window.  

He was alive. He had been given a chance.  

Tears streamed down his face as he fell to his knees, overcome with gratitude and remorse. "I will honor Christmas in my heart," he vowed, his voice trembling with newfound resolve. "I will keep it all the year. I will live to be a better man!"  

And with that, Ebenezer Scrooge—once a miser, now a man reborn—leapt to his feet, flinging open the window to greet the morning with a joyous shout. The bells of London rang out in celebration, and for the first time in many long years, Scrooge’s heart rang with them.  

For he had seen the shadows of what might be, and he was determined to walk instead in the light.

events.title: Meeting the Ghost of Christmas Present
detailed_summary: The Giant figure warmly invites Scrooge to enter the room and become better acquainted.
Scrooge steps inside timidly, his usual defiance replaced by humility, and he avoids meeting the Spirit's kind gaze.
The Spirit identifies himself as the Ghost of Christmas Present and commands Scrooge to look upon him.
Scrooge observes the Spirit's attire: a simple green robe bordered with white fur, worn loosely, revealing a bare chest.
The Spirit's feet are also bare, and his head is adorned only with a holly wreath accented with shining icicles.
His appearance is characterized by long, free dark brown curls, a genial face, sparkling eyes, an open hand, a cheerful voice, and an unconstrained, joyful manner.
An antique, empty, rust-eaten scabbard hangs at his waist.
The Spirit confirms that Scrooge has never encountered a being like him before.
He inquires if Scrooge has ever journeyed with any of his 'elder brothers' - the Ghosts of Christmas Present from previous years, explaining he himself is very young.
Scrooge admits he likely has not and asks if the Spirit has numerous brothers.
The Ghost reveals he has had 'more than eighteen hundred' brothers.
Scrooge quietly reflects on the immense responsibility of providing for such a vast family.

events.text_segment:
“Come in!” exclaimed the Ghost. “Come in! and know me better, man!”
Scrooge entered timidly, and hung his head before this Spirit. He was not the dogged Scrooge he had been; and though the Spirit’s eyes were clear and kind, he did not like to meet them.
“I am the Ghost of Christmas Present,” said the Spirit. “Look upon me!”
Scrooge reverently did so. It was clothed in one simple green robe, or mantle, bordered with white fur. This garment hung so loosely on the figure, that its capacious breast was bare, as if disdaining to be warded or concealed by any artifice. Its feet, observable beneath the ample folds of the garment, were also bare; and on its head it wore no other covering than a holly wreath, set here and there with shining icicles. Its dark brown curls were long and free; free as its genial face, its sparkling eye, its open hand, its cheery voice, its unconstrained demeanour, and its joyful air. Girded round its middle was an antique scabbard; but no sword was in it, and the ancient sheath was eaten up with rust.
“You have never seen the like of me before!” exclaimed the Spirit.
“Never,” Scrooge made answer to it.
“Have never walked forth with the younger members of my family; meaning (for I am very young) my elder brothers born in these later years?” pursued the Phantom.
“I don’t think I have,” said Scrooge. “I am afraid I have not. Have you had many brothers, Spirit?”
“More than eighteen hundred,” said the Ghost.
“A tremendous family to provide for!” muttered Scrooge.

The Ghost of Christmas Present rose.
“Spirit,” said Scrooge submissively, “conduct me where you will. I went forth last night on compulsion, and I learnt a lesson which is working now. To-night, if you have aught to teach me, let me profit by it.”
“Touch my robe!”

Holly, mistletoe, red berries, ivy, turkeys, geese, game, poultry, brawn, meat, pigs, sausages, oysters, pies, puddings, fruit, and punch, all vanished instantly. So did the room, the fire, the ruddy glow, the hour of night, and they stood in the city streets on Christmas morning, where (for the weather was severe) the people made a rough, but brisk and not unpleasant kind of music, in scraping the snow from the pavement in front of their dwellings, and from the tops of their houses, whence it was mad delight to the boys to see it come plumping down into the road below, and splitting into artificial little snow-storms.
The house fronts looked black enough, and the windows blacker, contrasting with the smooth white sheet of snow upon the roofs, and with the dirtier snow upon the ground; which last deposit had been ploughed up in deep furrows by the heavy wheels of carts and waggons; furrows that crossed and re-crossed each other hundreds of times where the great streets branched off; and made intricate channels, hard to trace in the thick yellow mud and icy water. The sky was gloomy, and the shortest streets were choked up with a dingy mist, half thawed, half frozen, whose heavier particles descended in a shower of sooty atoms, as if all the chimneys in Great Britain had, by one consent, caught fire, and were blazing away to their dear hearts’ content.

There was nothing very cheerful in the climate or the town, and yet was there an air of cheerfulness abroad that the clearest summer air and brightest summer sun might have endeavoured to diffuse in vain.
For, the people who were shovelling away on the housetops were jovial and full of glee; calling out to one another from the parapets, and now and then exchanging a facetious snowball—better-natured missile far than many a wordy jest—laughing heartily if it went right and not less heartily if it went wrong. The poulterers’ shops were still half open, and the fruiterers’ were radiant in their glory. There were great, round, pot-bellied baskets of chestnuts, shaped like the waistcoats of jolly old gentlemen, lolling at the doors, and tumbling out into the street in their apoplectic opulence. There were ruddy, brown-faced, broad-girthed Spanish Onions, shining in the fatness of their growth like Spanish Friars, and winking from their shelves in wanton slyness at the girls as they went by, and glanced demurely at the hung-up mistletoe. There were pears and apples, clustered high in blooming pyramids; there were bunches of grapes, made, in the shopkeepers’ benevolence to dangle from conspicuous hooks, that people’s mouths might water gratis as they passed; there were piles of filberts, mossy and brown, recalling, in their fragrance, ancient walks among the woods, and pleasant shufflings ankle deep through withered leaves; there were Norfolk Biffins, squat and swarthy, setting off the yellow of the oranges and lemons, and, in the great compactness of their juicy persons, urgently entreating and beseeching to be carried home in paper bags and eaten after dinner. The very gold and silver fish, set forth among these choice fruits in a bowl, though members of a dull and stagnant-blooded race, appeared to know that there was something going on; and, to a fish, went gasping round and round their little world in slow and passionless excitement.
The Grocers’! oh, the Grocers’! nearly closed, with perhaps two shutters down, or one; but through those gaps such glimpses! It was not alone that the scales descending on the counter made a merry sound, or that the twine and roller parted company so briskly, or that the canisters were rattled up and down like juggling tricks, or even that the blended scents of tea and coffee were so grateful to the nose, or even that the raisins were so plentiful and rare, the almonds so extremely white, the sticks of cinnamon so long and straight, the other spices so delicious, the candied fruits so caked and spotted with molten sugar as to make the coldest lookers-on feel faint and subsequently bilious. Nor was it that the figs were moist and pulpy, or that the French plums blushed in modest tartness from their highly-decorated boxes, or that everything was good to eat and in its Christmas dress; but the customers were all so hurried and so eager in the hopeful promise of the day, that they tumbled up against each other at the door, crashing their wicker baskets wildly, and left their purchases upon the counter, and came running back to fetch them, and committed hundreds of the like mistakes, in the best humour possible; while the Grocer and his people were so frank and fresh that the polished hearts with which they fastened their aprons behind might have been their own, worn outside for general inspection, and for Christmas daws to peck at if they chose.
But soon the steeples called good people all, to church and chapel, and away they came, flocking through the streets in their best clothes, and with their gayest faces. And at the same time there emerged from scores of bye-streets, lanes, and nameless turnings, innumerable people, carrying their dinners to the bakers’ shops. The sight of these poor revellers appeared to interest the Spirit very much, for he stood with Scrooge beside him in a baker’s doorway, and taking off the covers as their bearers passed, sprinkled incense on their dinners from his torch. And it was a very uncommon kind of torch, for once or twice when there were angry words between some dinner-carriers who had jostled each other, he shed a few drops of water on them from it, and their good humour was restored directly. For they said, it was a shame to quarrel upon Christmas Day. And so it was! God love it, so it was!
In time the bells ceased, and the bakers were shut up; and yet there was a genial shadowing forth of all these dinners and the progress of their cooking, in the thawed blotch of wet above each baker’s oven; where the pavement smoked as if its stones were cooking too.
“Is there a peculiar flavour in what you sprinkle from your torch?” asked Scrooge.
“There is. My own.”
“Would it apply to any kind of dinner on this day?” asked Scrooge.
“To any kindly given. To a poor one most.”
“Why to a poor one most?” asked Scrooge.
“Because it needs it most.”
“Spirit,” said Scrooge, after a moment’s thought, “I wonder you, of all the beings in the many worlds about us, should desire to cramp these people’s opportunities of innocent enjoyment.”
“I!” cried the Spirit.
“You would deprive them of their means of dining every seventh day, often the only day on which they can be said to dine at all,” said Scrooge. “Wouldn’t you?”
“I!” cried the Spirit.
“You seek to close these places on the Seventh Day?” said Scrooge. “And it comes to the same thing.”
“I seek!” exclaimed the Spirit.
“Forgive me if I am wrong. It has been done in your name, or at least in that of your family,” said Scrooge.
“There are some upon this earth of yours,” returned the Spirit, “who lay claim to know us, and who do their deeds of passion, pride, ill-will, hatred, envy, bigotry, and selfishness in our name, who are as strange to us and all our kith and kin, as if they had never lived. Remember that, and charge their doings on themselves, not us.”

The poorest beggar, huddled in a doorway, found a crust of bread pressed into his hand by a passerby whose own pockets were far from full. The surliest tradesman, who grumbled year-round about the folly of mankind, softened just enough to toss a coin into the kettle of a street musician playing *God Rest Ye Merry, Gentlemen* on a battered fiddle.  

And why not? For Christmas was a time when the world, if only for a day, seemed to remember its better nature. The rich remembered the poor, the proud remembered the humble, and even the miserly might, if only for an hour, unclench their fists. detailed_summary: Scrooge affirms he will remember the Spirit's words, and they proceed invisibly towards the city's suburbs.
Scrooge marvels at the Ghost's ability to adapt his massive size to any space gracefully.
Driven perhaps by kindness, sympathy for the poor, or a desire to display his power, the Spirit leads Scrooge directly to Bob Cratchit's home.
At the threshold, the Spirit smiles and blesses the humble four-room dwelling with his torch, despite Bob's meager weekly wage of fifteen shillings.
Inside, Mrs. Cratchit, wearing a worn but ribbon-adorned gown, prepares the table with her daughter Belinda.
Master Peter Cratchit checks the boiling potatoes, feeling proud in his oversized hand-me-down collar, which hinders him slightly.
Two younger Cratchits burst in, announcing they smelled their goose cooking at the baker's, and dance excitedly, praising Peter as he tends the fire.
Mrs. Cratchit expresses concern over the lateness of Bob, Tiny Tim, and Martha.
Martha arrives, explaining a delay due to work, and is warmly welcomed by her mother.
As Bob approaches, the younger children urge Martha to hide as a playful surprise.
Bob enters, his threadbare clothes neatened for the occasion, carrying Tiny Tim, who relies on a crutch and an iron frame for support.
Bob asks for Martha, showing genuine disappointment when jokingly told she isn't coming.
Martha quickly reveals herself, unwilling to prolong his disappointment, and they embrace warmly.
The younger children escort Tiny Tim to the wash-house to hear the Christmas pudding boiling.
Mrs. Cratchit inquires about Tim's behavior in church.
Bob emotionally recounts that Tim behaved 'as good as gold,' adding that Tim hoped people saw him, a cripple, to remember on Christmas Day who performed miracles for the lame and blind.
Bob's voice shakes as he shares this and expresses hope that Tim is growing stronger.
Tiny Tim returns to his stool by the fire, escorted by his siblings.
Bob prepares a hot gin and lemon punch while Master Peter and the two youngest Cratchits leave to fetch the cooked goose, returning shortly in a proud procession.

Scrooge promised that he would; and they went on, invisible, as they had been before, into the suburbs of the town. It was a remarkable quality of the Ghost (which Scrooge had observed at the baker’s), that notwithstanding his gigantic size, he could accommodate himself to any place with ease; and that he stood beneath a low roof quite as gracefully and like a supernatural creature, as it was possible he could have done in any lofty hall.
And perhaps it was the pleasure the good Spirit had in showing off this power of his, or else it was his own kind, generous, hearty nature, and his sympathy with all poor men, that led him straight to Scrooge’s clerk’s; for there he went, and took Scrooge with him, holding to his robe; and on the threshold of the door the Spirit smiled, and stopped to bless Bob Cratchit’s dwelling with the sprinkling of his torch. Think of that! Bob had but fifteen “Bob” a-week himself; he pocketed on Saturdays but fifteen copies of his Christian name; and yet the Ghost of Christmas Present blessed his four-roomed house!
Then up rose Mrs. Cratchit, Cratchit’s wife, dressed out but poorly in a twice-turned gown, but brave in ribbons, which are cheap and make a goodly show for sixpence; and she laid the cloth, assisted by Belinda Cratchit, second of her daughters, also brave in ribbons; while Master Peter Cratchit plunged a fork into the saucepan of potatoes, and getting the corners of his monstrous shirt collar (Bob’s private property, conferred upon his son and heir in honour of the day) into his mouth, rejoiced to find himself so gallantly attired, and yearned to show his linen in the fashionable Parks. And now two smaller Cratchits, boy and girl, came tearing in, screaming that outside the baker’s they had smelt the goose, and known it for their own; and basking in luxurious thoughts of sage and onion, these young Cratchits danced about the table, and exalted Master Peter Cratchit to the skies, while he (not proud, although his collars nearly choked him) blew the fire, until the slow potatoes bubbling up, knocked loudly at the saucepan-lid to be let out and peeled.
“What has ever got your precious father then?” said Mrs. Cratchit. “And your brother, Tiny Tim! And Martha warn’t as late last Christmas Day by half-an-hour?”
“Here’s Martha, mother!” said a girl, appearing as she spoke.
“Here’s Martha, mother!” cried the two young Cratchits. “Hurrah! There’s such a goose, Martha!”
“Why, bless your heart alive, my dear, how late you are!” said Mrs. Cratchit, kissing her a dozen times, and taking off her shawl and bonnet for her with officious zeal.
“We’d a deal of work to finish up last night,” replied the girl, “and had to clear away this morning, mother!”
“Well! Never mind so long as you are come,” said Mrs. Cratchit. “Sit ye down before the fire, my dear, and have a warm, Lord bless ye!”
“No, no! There’s father coming,” cried the two young Cratchits, who were everywhere at once. “Hide, Martha, hide!”
So Martha hid herself, and in came little Bob, the father, with at least three feet of comforter exclusive of the fringe, hanging down before him; and his threadbare clothes darned up and brushed, to look seasonable; and Tiny Tim upon his shoulder. Alas for Tiny Tim, he bore a little crutch, and had his limbs supported by an iron frame!
“Why, where’s our Martha?” cried Bob Cratchit, looking round.
“Not coming,” said Mrs. Cratchit.
“Not coming!” said Bob, with a sudden declension in his high spirits; for he had been Tim’s blood horse all the way from church, and had come home rampant. “Not coming upon Christmas Day!”
Martha didn’t like to see him disappointed, if it were only in joke; so she came out prematurely from behind the closet door, and ran into his arms, while the two young Cratchits hustled Tiny Tim, and bore him off into the wash-house, that he might hear the pudding singing in the copper.
“And how did little Tim behave?” asked Mrs. Cratchit, when she had rallied Bob on his credulity, and Bob had hugged his daughter to his heart’s content.
“As good as gold,” said Bob, “and better. Somehow he gets thoughtful, sitting by himself so much, and thinks the strangest things you ever heard. He told me, coming home, that he hoped the people saw him in the church, because he was a cripple, and it might be pleasant to them to remember upon Christmas Day, who made lame beggars walk, and blind men see.”
Bob’s voice was tremulous when he told them this, and trembled more when he said that Tiny Tim was growing strong and hearty.
His active little crutch was heard upon the floor, and back came Tiny Tim before another word was spoken, escorted by his brother and sister to his stool before the fire; and while Bob, turning up his cuffs—as if, poor fellow, they were capable of being made more shabby—compounded some hot mixture in a jug with gin and lemons, and stirred it round and round and put it on the hob to simmer; Master Peter, and the two ubiquitous young Cratchits went to fetch the goose, with which they soon returned in high procession.

Scrooge promised that he would; and they went on, invisible, as they had been before, into the suburbs of the town. The streets were quieter here, the houses smaller and humbler, yet there was a warmth in the air that had been absent in the bustling heart of London. The snow fell gently, muffling their footsteps, though none could see them pass.  

As they walked, the Ghost of Christmas Present spread his torch wide, casting its golden glow upon the windows of the cottages they passed. Within, families gathered—fathers, mothers, children—laughing, singing, feasting. The sight stirred something deep within Scrooge’s heart, a longing he had long suppressed.  

“Spirit,” he said at last, his voice unsteady, “tell me—are these the shadows of things that *must* be, or are they shadows of things that *may* be only?”  

The Spirit turned his kind, yet solemn, gaze upon Scrooge. “They are the shadows of what *is*,” he replied. “Would you deny them their joy?”  

Scrooge shook his head. “No, no. But I wonder—if a man were to change, could he alter the fate of those around him?”  

The Ghost did not answer at once. Instead, he led Scrooge onward until they came to a small, ramshackle dwelling, its roof sagging under the weight of snow. Through the thin walls, they heard the sound of laughter—frail but genuine.  

Inside, a meager fire burned in the hearth, yet the room was filled with light. A woman sat by the fire, her hands busy with needlework, while a thin but cheerful man—Bob Cratchit—carved a small goose at the table. Around him, his children chattered excitedly, their faces alight with happiness despite their threadbare clothes.  

And there, in the corner, sat Tiny Tim upon a little stool, his crutch leaning against the wall. His voice, though weak, rose above the others as he sang a carol, his eyes shining with innocent joy.  

Scrooge’s breath caught in his throat. “Spirit,” he whispered, “tell me—will Tiny Tim live?”  

The Ghost’s expression darkened. “I see a vacant seat in the poor chimney-corner,” he said softly, “and a crutch without an owner, carefully preserved. If these shadows remain unaltered by the future, the child will die.”  

Scrooge’s hands clenched. “No,” he said hoarsely. “No, surely there must be some mercy—”  

“What then?” the Ghost interrupted. “If he is to die, he had better do it, and decrease the surplus population.”  

The words struck Scrooge like a blow. He recoiled, his face twisting in anguish. “No! Those were my words—my cruel, thoughtless words!” He fell to his knees, his voice breaking. “Spirit, tell me—is there yet time? Can I change this?”  

The Ghost regarded him silently for a long moment. Then, without a word, he raised his torch once more, and the scene shifted. They stood now in a bustling marketplace, where people hurried to and fro, laden with last-minute purchases for their Christmas feasts. Among them, Scrooge saw his nephew, Fred, laughing with his wife and friends, their faces bright with merriment.  

“Come, come!” Fred was saying. “Uncle Scrooge may not join us, but we shall drink to his health all the same! A merry Christmas to him, whether he likes it or not!”  

The others cheered, raising their glasses, and Scrooge felt a strange tightness in his chest. He had scorned such kindness all his life, yet here it was, offered freely despite his bitterness.  

The Ghost turned to him. “Do you see now, Ebenezer Scrooge? The world is full of joy, if only you would open your heart to it.”  

Scrooge could not speak. His eyes burned with unshed tears as he watched the people around him—loving, laughing, living. How much time had he wasted in darkness? How many chances for happiness had he cast aside?  

At last, the Ghost’s form began to fade, his robe growing dimmer, his light flickering like a dying candle.  

“My time grows short,” he said. “Look upon me well, for soon I shall be gone.”  

Scrooge reached out, desperate. “Wait! There is so much more I must know—so much I must understand!”  

But the Ghost only smiled sadly. “Remember what you have seen, Ebenezer Scrooge. Remember, and learn.”  

And with those final words, the Spirit vanished, leaving Scrooge alone in the swirling snow.  

For a long moment, Scrooge stood motionless, his mind reeling. Then, with a sudden, fierce determination, he clenched his fists.  

“I *will* change,” he vowed to the empty air. “I *will* honor Christmas in my heart, and try to keep it all the year!”  

And with that, he turned and ran—ran through the streets, past the houses, past the joyful sounds of celebration, toward the future that now lay open before him.  

For the first time in many, many years, Ebenezer Scrooge was eager to live.

events.title: The Cratchit Family Christmas - Part 2: Dinner, Toast, and Tim's Fate
detailed_summary: The goose's arrival creates immense excitement, treated as a rare treasure, which it essentially is for the Cratchit family.

The family works together seamlessly for the meal: Mrs. Cratchit heats gravy, Peter mashes potatoes vigorously, Belinda prepares applesauce, Martha handles plates, Bob settles Tiny Tim beside him, and the youngest position chairs, suppressing their urge to shout for goose.
Following grace, Mrs. Cratchit carves the goose, eliciting murmurs of delight as the stuffing emerges; even Tiny Tim taps his knife handle on the table in excitement.
The goose is universally praised for its tenderness, flavor, size, and affordability, providing a sufficient meal for everyone when combined with the side dishes.
Mrs. Cratchit proudly observes that a tiny bit remained uneaten.
After the main course, Mrs. Cratchit nervously leaves to retrieve the pudding, while the family anxiously imagines potential kitchen calamities.
She returns flushed but proud, carrying the pudding – hard, firm, resembling a speckled cannonball, flaming with ignited brandy and adorned with holly.

The pudding receives ecstatic praise; Bob declares it Mrs. Cratchit's greatest culinary achievement since their marriage. Everyone agrees it's a wonderful pudding, ignoring any suggestion it might be small for their number.
Dinner concludes, the table is cleared, the hearth swept, and the fire tended.
The family gathers around the hearth with fruit, roasting chestnuts, and the hot punch served in their mismatched collection of glassware.
Bob cheerfully serves the punch as the chestnuts crackle.
He proposes a toast: 'A Merry Christmas to us all, my dears. God bless us!'
The family joyfully echoes the sentiment.
Tiny Tim, seated close to his father, adds the final, poignant line: 'God bless us every one!'
Bob holds Tim's small, withered hand tightly, conveying deep love and a fear of losing him.
Deeply affected, Scrooge asks the Spirit with unprecedented interest if Tiny Tim will live.

The Ghost responds by describing a future vision: an empty seat in the chimney corner and a carefully preserved, ownerless crutch, stating, 'If these shadows remain unaltered by the Future, the child will die.'
Scrooge desperately pleads, 'Oh, no, kind Spirit! say he will be spared.'

The Ghost sternly repeats that if the future is unchanged, none of his successors will find Tim there, then directly quotes Scrooge's earlier Malthusian remark: 'What then? If he be like to die, he had better do it, and decrease the surplus population.'
Hearing his own callous words used against him, Scrooge hangs his head, overwhelmed by penitence and grief.
The Ghost delivers a powerful rebuke, warning Scrooge to abandon such 'wicked cant' until he understands the true nature of the 'surplus.'
The Spirit questions Scrooge's authority to judge who lives or dies, suggesting that in Heaven's view, Scrooge might be less worthy than millions like Tiny Tim.
It likens Scrooge's pronouncements to an insect judging the lives of its 'hungry brothers in the dust.'

Such a bustle ensued that you might have thought a goose the rarest of all birds; a feathered phenomenon, to which a black swan was a matter of course—and in truth it was something very like it in that house. Then all the Cratchit family drew round the hearth, in what Bob Cratchit called a circle, meaning half a one; and at Bob Cratchit’s elbow stood the family display of glass. Two tumblers, and a custard-cup without a handle.
These held the hot stuff from the jug, however, as well as golden goblets would have done; and Bob served it out with beaming looks, while the chestnuts on the fire sputtered and cracked noisily. Then Bob proposed:

Which all the family re-echoed.
“God bless us every one!” said Tiny Tim, the last of all.
He sat very close to his father’s side upon his little stool. Bob held his withered little hand in his, as if he loved the child, and wished to keep him by his side, and dreaded that he might be taken from him.
“Spirit,” said Scrooge, with an interest he had never felt before, “tell me if Tiny Tim will live.”
“I see a vacant seat,” replied the Ghost, “in the poor chimney-corner, and a crutch without an owner, carefully preserved. If these shadows remain unaltered by the Future, the child will die.”
“No, no,” said Scrooge. “Oh, no, kind Spirit! say he will be spared.”
“If these shadows remain unaltered by the Future, none other of my race,” returned the Ghost, “will find him here. What then? If he be like to die, he had better do it, and decrease the surplus population.”
Scrooge hung his head to hear his own words quoted by the Spirit, and was overcome with penitence and grief.
“Man,” said the Ghost, “if man you be in heart, not adamant, forbear that wicked cant until you have discovered What the surplus is, and Where it is. Will you decide what men shall live, what men shall die? It may be, that in the sight of Heaven, you are more worthless and less fit to live than millions like this poor man’s child. Oh God! to hear the Insect on the leaf pronouncing on the too much life among his hungry brothers in the dust!”

Such a bustle ensued that you might have thought a goose the rarest of all birds; a feathered phenomenon, to which a black swan was a matter of course—and in truth it was something very like it in that house.  

For in the humble dwelling of the Cratchit family, where pennies were counted and coal was sparingly doled out, the arrival of the Christmas goose was nothing short of a miracle. Bob Cratchit had scarcely believed his eyes when he returned home with the prize clutched tightly under his arm, its plumpness a promise of unlooked-for abundance. His wife, Mrs. Cratchit, flushed with excitement, had nearly dropped the potatoes she was peeling in her haste to inspect it.  

"Upon my word!" she cried, her hands fluttering like the wings of the very bird in question. "However did you manage it, Bob?"  

Bob, though weary from his long hours at Scrooge’s counting-house, stood a little straighter, his face alight with quiet pride. "A little saving here and there," he said modestly, though the truth was he had gone without a second coat all winter to afford it.  

The children, who had been hovering like a flock of eager sparrows, now burst into cheers. Tiny Tim, perched upon his little crutch, clapped his hands with delight. "Oh, Father! It’s the finest goose I ever saw!"  

And indeed, it was a fine goose—large, golden-skinned (or so it would be once roasted), and more than enough to feed them all with leftovers to spare. The very sight of it seemed to warm the room more than the meager fire in the grate.  

Mrs. Cratchit, now recovered from her astonishment, set to work at once, marshaling her forces with the skill of a general. Peter was dispatched to the baker’s with the pudding, which had been steaming all morning in the wash copper. The two young Cratchits, whose names were scarcely ever mentioned without the prefix "the little," were tasked with setting the table, a duty they performed with much clattering of plates and giggling. Belinda, the eldest daughter, was set to mashing the potatoes with a vigor that sent flecks of butter flying.  

Meanwhile, the goose was spitted, seasoned, and set before the fire, where it began to sizzle and brown, filling the cramped little kitchen with a fragrance so rich it seemed to mock the very idea of want.  

Bob, watching the proceedings with a smile, drew Tiny Tim close to his side. "This will be a Christmas to remember, my boy," he murmured.  

Tim nodded solemnly, his large eyes reflecting the firelight. "God bless us, every one," he said softly.  

And for a moment, in that humble room, with the goose turning on its spit and the pudding bubbling in its cloth, it seemed as though heaven itself had stooped to touch them. The shadows that usually clung to the corners—shadows of debt, of cold, of hunger—were banished by the glow of the fire and the laughter of the children.  

When at last the meal was ready, the family gathered around the table, their faces shining with anticipation. Bob, carving the goose with a solemnity befitting a king’s feast, served each plate with generous slices, while Mrs. Cratchit ladled out gravy with a lavish hand.  

And as they ate—oh, how they ate!—there was not a soul among them who did not feel, if only for that one golden hour, that they were the richest family in all of London.  

For in the end, it was not the size of the goose or the cost of the pudding that made their Christmas feast so splendid. It was the love that seasoned every bite, the joy that filled every corner of the room, and the unshakable belief that, no matter how hard the times, there was always room for a little kindness, a little hope, and a little magic at Christmas.  

And so, with full hearts and fuller stomachs, the Cratchits celebrated their humble feast, proving once more that the spirit of Christmas could transform even the simplest of meals into a banquet fit for kings.

Throughout this, chestnuts and punch are enjoyed.

events.text_segment:
Scrooge bent before the Ghost’s rebuke, and trembling cast his eyes upon the ground. But he raised them speedily, on hearing his own name.
“Mr. Scrooge!” said Bob; “I’ll give you Mr. Scrooge, the Founder of the Feast!”
“The Founder of the Feast indeed!” cried Mrs. Cratchit, reddening. “I wish I had him here. I’d give him a piece of my mind to feast upon, and I hope he’d have a good appetite for it.”
“My dear,” said Bob, “the children! Christmas Day.”
“It should be Christmas Day, I am sure,” said she, “on which one drinks the health of such an odious, stingy, hard, unfeeling man as Mr. Scrooge. You know he is, Robert! Nobody knows it better than you do, poor fellow!”
“My dear,” was Bob’s mild answer, “Christmas Day.”
“I’ll drink his health for your sake and the Day’s,” said Mrs. Cratchit, “not for his. Long life to him! A merry Christmas and a happy new year! He’ll be very merry and very happy, I have no doubt!”
The children drank the toast after her. It was the first of their proceedings which had no heartiness. Tiny Tim drank it last of all, but he didn’t care twopence for it. Scrooge was the Ogre of the family. The mention of his name cast a dark shadow on the party, which was not dispelled for full five minutes.
After it had passed away, they were ten times merrier than before, from the mere relief of Scrooge the Baleful being done with. Bob Cratchit told them how he had a situation in his eye for Master Peter, which would bring in, if obtained, full five-and-sixpence weekly. The two young Cratchits laughed tremendously at the idea of Peter’s being a man of business; and Peter himself looked thoughtfully at the fire from between his collars, as if he were deliberating what particular investments he should favour when he came into the receipt of that bewildering income. Martha, who was a poor apprentice at a milliner’s, then told them what kind of work she had to do, and how many hours she worked at a stretch, and how she meant to lie abed to-morrow morning for a good long rest; to-morrow being a holiday she passed at home. Also how she had seen a countess and a lord some days before, and how the lord “was much about as tall as Peter;” at which Peter pulled up his collars so high that you couldn’t have seen his head if you had been there. All this time the chestnuts and the jug went round and round; and by-and-bye they had a song, about a lost child travelling in the snow, from Tiny Tim, who had a plaintive little voice, and sang it very well indeed.
There was nothing of high mark in this. They were not a handsome family; they were not well dressed; their shoes were far from being water-proof; their clothes were scanty; and Peter might have known, and very likely did, the inside of a pawnbroker’s. But, they were happy, grateful, pleased with one another, and contented with the time; and when they faded, and looked happier yet in the bright sprinklings of the Spirit’s torch at parting, Scrooge had his eye upon them, and especially on Tiny Tim, until the last.

Also how she had seen a countess and a lord some days before, and how the lord “was much about as tall as Peter;” at which Peter pulled up his collars so high that you couldn’t have seen his head if you had been there. All this time the chestnuts and the jug went round and round; and by-and-bye they had a song, about a lost child travelling in the snow, from Tiny Tim, who had a plaintive little voice, and sang it very well indeed.  

There was nothing of high mark in this. They were not a handsome family; they were not well dressed; their shoes were far from being water-proof; their clothes were scanty; and Peter might have known, and very likely did, the inside of a pawnbroker’s. But they were happy, grateful, pleased with one another, and contented with the time; and when they faded, and looked happier yet in the bright sprinklings of the Spirit’s torch at parting, Scrooge had his eye upon them, and especially on Tiny Tim, until the last.  

---
